http://edamontology.org/topic_0749.description: Proteins that bind to DNA and control transcription of DNA to mRNA (transcription factors) and also transcriptional regulatory sites, elements and regions (such as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators) in nucleotide sequences.|Transcription factor proteins either promote (as an activator) or block (as a repressor) the binding to DNA of RNA polymerase.  Regulatory sites including transcription factor binding site as well as promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators.|This includes CpG rich regions (isochores) in a nucleotide sequence.|This includes promoters, CAAT signals, TATA signals, -35 signals, -10 signals, GC signals, primer binding sites for initiation of transcription or reverse transcription, enhancer, attenuator, terminators and ribosome binding sites.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0199.label: Genetic variation
http://edamontology.org/topic_0199.description: Stable, naturally occuring mutations in a nucleotide sequence including alleles, naturally occurring mutations such as single base nucleotide substitutions, deletions and insertions, RFLPs and other polymorphisms.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3175.label: DNA structural variation
http://edamontology.org/topic_3175.description: Variation in chromosome structure including microscopic and submicroscopic types of variation such as deletions, duplications, copy-number variants, insertions, inversions and translocations.

synonyms: Variable number of tandem repeat polymorphism
http://edamontology.org/topic_2885.label: DNA polymorphism
http://edamontology.org/topic_2885.description: DNA polymorphism.|Includes microsatellite polymorphism in a DNA sequence.  A microsatellite polymorphism is a very short subsequence that is repeated a variable number of times between individuals. These repeats consist of the nucleotides cytosine and adenosine.|Includes restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLP) in a DNA sequence.  An RFLP is defined by the presence or absence of a specific restriction site of a bacterial restriction enzyme.|Includes single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) and associated data, for example, the discovery and annotation of SNPs.  A SNP is a DNA sequence variation where a single nucleotide differs between members of a species or paired chromosomes in an individual.|Includes variable number of tandem repeat (VNTR) polymorphism in a DNA sequence.  VNTRs occur in non-coding regions of DNA and consists sub-sequence that is repeated a multiple (and varied) number of times.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0114.label: Gene structure
http://edamontology.org/topic_0114.description: Gene structure, regions which make an RNA product and features such as promoters, coding regions, gene fusion, splice sites etc.|This includes the study of promoters, coding regions etc.|This incudes operons (operators, promoters and genes) from a bacterial genome.  For example the operon leader and trailer gene, gene composition of the operon and associated information.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3512.label: Gene transcripts
http://edamontology.org/topic_3512.description: Transcription of DNA into RNA and features of a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules including precursor RNA, primary (unprocessed) transcript and fully processed molecules.|This includes 5'untranslated region (5'UTR), coding sequences (CDS), exons, intervening sequences (intron) and 3'untranslated regions (3'UTR).|This includes regions or sites in a eukaryotic and eukaryotic viral RNA sequence which directs endonuclease cleavage or polyadenylation of an RNA transcript.  A polyA signal is required for endonuclease cleavage of an RNA transcript that is followed by polyadenylation. A polyA site is a site on an RNA transcript to which adenine residues will be added during post-transcriptional polyadenylation.|This includes Introns, and protein-coding regions including coding sequences (CDS), exons, translation initiation sites and open reading frames.  Also expressed sequence tag (EST) or complementary DNA (cDNA) sequences.|This includes coding sequences for a signal or transit peptide.  A signal peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a secreted protein, which is involved in attaching the polypeptide to a membrane leader sequence. A transit peptide coding sequence encodes an N-terminal domain of a nuclear-encoded organellar protein; which is involved in import of the protein into the organelle.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0798.label: Mobile genetic elements
http://edamontology.org/topic_0798.description: Mobile genetic elements, such as transposons, Plasmids, Bacteriophage elements and Group II introns.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0659.label: Functional, regulatory and non-coding RNA
http://edamontology.org/topic_0659.description: Non-coding or functional RNA sequences, including regulatory RNA sequences, ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and transfer RNA (tRNA).|Non-coding RNA includes  piwi-interacting RNA (piRNA), small nuclear RNA (snRNA) and small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA).  Regulatory RNA includes microRNA (miRNA) - short single stranded RNA molecules that regulate gene expression, and small interfering RNA (siRNA).

http://edamontology.org/topic_3295.label: Epigenetics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3295.description: Topic concerning the study of heritable changes, for example in gene expression or phenotype, caused by mechanisms other than changes in the DNA sequence.|This includes sub-topics such as histone modification and DNA methylation (methylation sites and analysis, for example of patterns and profiles of DNA methylation in a population, tissue etc.)

http://edamontology.org/topic_3173.label: Epigenomics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3173.description: The study of the epigenetic modifications of a whole cell, tissue, organism etc.|Epigenetics concerns the heritable changes in gene expression owing to mechanisms other than DNA sequence variation.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3056.label: Population genetics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3056.description: The distribution of allele frequencies in a population of organisms and its change subject to evolutionary processes including natural selection, genetic drift, mutation and gene flow.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0625.label: Genotype and phenotype
http://edamontology.org/topic_0625.description: The study of genetic constitution of a living entity, such as an individual, and organism, a cell and so on, typically with respect to a particular observable phenotypic traits, or resources concerning such traits, which might be an aspect of biochemistry, physiology, morphology, anatomy, development and so on.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3298.label: Phenomics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3298.description: Phenomes, or the study of the change in phenotype (the physical and biochemical traits of organisms) in response to genetic and environmental factors.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3055.label: Quantitative genetics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3055.description: The genes and genetic mechanisms such as Mendelian inheritance that underly continuous phenotypic traits (such as height or weight).

http://edamontology.org/topic_3047.label: Molecular biology
http://edamontology.org/topic_3047.description: The molecular basis of biological activity, particularly the macromolecules (e.g. proteins and nucleic acids) that are essential to life.

http://edamontology.org/topic_2815.label: Human biology
http://edamontology.org/topic_2815.description: The study of human beings in general, including the human genome and proteome.

http://edamontology.org/topic_2259.label: Systems biology
http://edamontology.org/topic_2259.description: The holistic modelling and analysis of complex biological systems and the interactions therein.|This includes databases of models and methods to construct or analyse a model.

http://edamontology.org/topic_2229.label: Cell biology
http://edamontology.org/topic_2229.description: Cells, such as key genes and proteins involved in the cell cycle.

http://edamontology.org/topic_1317.label: Structural biology
http://edamontology.org/topic_1317.description: The molecular structure of biological molecules, particularly macromolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids.|This includes experimental methods for biomolecular structure determination, such as X-ray crystallography, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy, microscopy etc., including the assignment or modelling of molecular structure from such data.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3448.label: Neutron diffraction
http://edamontology.org/topic_3448.description: The study of matter by studying the diffraction pattern from firing neutrons at a sample, typically to determine atomic and/or magnetic structure.

http://edamontology.org/topic_2828.label: X-ray diffraction
http://edamontology.org/topic_2828.description: The study of matter and their structure by means of the diffraction of X-rays, typically the diffraction pattern caused by the regularly spaced atoms of a crystalline sample.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0611.label: Electron microscopy
http://edamontology.org/topic_0611.description: The study of matter by studying the interference pattern from firing electrons at a sample, to analyse structures at resolutions higher than can be achieved using light.

synonyms: Rotational Frame Nuclear Overhauser Effect Spectroscopy
http://edamontology.org/topic_0593.label: NMR
http://edamontology.org/topic_0593.description: An analytical technique that exploits the magenetic properties of certain atomic nuclei to provide information on the structure, dynamics, reaction state and chemical environment of molecules.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0122.label: Structural genomics
http://edamontology.org/topic_0122.description: The elucidation of the three dimensional structure for all (available) proteins in a given organism.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0781.label: Virology
http://edamontology.org/topic_0781.description: Study of viruses, e.g. sequence and structural data, interactions of viral proteins, or a viral genome including molecular sequences, genes and annotation.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0780.label: Plant biology
http://edamontology.org/topic_0780.description: Plants, e.g. information on a specific plant genome including molecular sequences, genes and annotation.|The resource may be specific to a plant, a group of plants or all plants.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0621.label: Model organisms
http://edamontology.org/topic_0621.description: A specific organism, or group of organisms, used to study a particular aspect of biology.|This may include information on the genome (including molecular sequences and map, genes and annotation), proteome, as well as more general information about an organism.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0610.label: Ecology
http://edamontology.org/topic_0610.description: The ecological and environmental sciences and especially the application of information technology (ecoinformatics).

http://edamontology.org/topic_3697.label: Microbial ecology
http://edamontology.org/topic_3697.description: The ecology of microorganisms including their relationship with one another and their environment.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3174.label: Metagenomics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3174.description: The study of genetic material recovered from environmental samples, and associated environmental data.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3050.label: Biodiversity
http://edamontology.org/topic_3050.description: The degree of variation of life forms within a given ecosystem, biome or an entire planet.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3068.label: Literature and language
http://edamontology.org/topic_3068.description: The scientific literature, language processing, reference information, and documentation.|This includes the documentation of resources such as tools, services and databases, user support, how to get help etc.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0218.label: Natural language processing
http://edamontology.org/topic_0218.description: The processing and analysis of natural language, such as scientific literature in English, in order to extract data and information, or to enable human-computer interaction.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0605.label: Informatics
http://edamontology.org/topic_0605.description: The study and practice of information processing and use of computer information systems.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3071.label: Data management
http://edamontology.org/topic_3071.description: The development and use of architectures, policies, practices and procedures for management of data.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3572.label: Data quality management
http://edamontology.org/topic_3572.description: The quality, integrity, and cleaning up of data.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3571.label: Data governance
http://edamontology.org/topic_3571.description: The control of data entry and maintenance to ensure the data meets defined standards, qualities or constraints.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3489.label: Database management
http://edamontology.org/topic_3489.description: The general handling of data stored in digital archives such as databanks, databases proper, web portals and other data resources.|This includes databases for the results of scientific experiments, the application of high-throughput technology, computational analysis and the scientific literature.  It covers the management and manipulation of digital documents, including database records, files and reports.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3366.label: Data integration and warehousing
http://edamontology.org/topic_3366.description: The combination and integration of data from different sources, for example into a central repository or warehouse, to provide users with a unified view of these data.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3365.label: Data architecture, analysis and design
http://edamontology.org/topic_3365.description: The development of policies, models and standards that cover data acquisition, storage and integration, such that it can be put to use, typically through a process of systematically applying statistical and / or logical techniques to describe, illustrate, summarise or evaluate data.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3345.label: Data identity and mapping
http://edamontology.org/topic_3345.description: Topic concerning the identity of biological entities, or reports on such entities, and the mapping of entities and records in different databases.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3263.label: Data security
http://edamontology.org/topic_3263.description: The protection of data, such as patient health data, from damage or unwanted access from unauthorised users.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3077.label: Data acquisition
http://edamontology.org/topic_3077.description: The acquisition of data, typically measurements of physical systems using any type of sampling system, or by another other means.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0769.label: Workflows
http://edamontology.org/topic_0769.description: Biological or biomedical analytical workflows or pipelines.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0219.label: Data submission, annotation and curation
http://edamontology.org/topic_0219.description: Deposition and curation of database accessions, including annotation, typically with terms from a controlled vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/topic_3063.label: Medical informatics
http://edamontology.org/topic_3063.description: The application of information technology to health, disease and biomedicine.

http://edamontology.org/topic_2258.label: Cheminformatics
http://edamontology.org/topic_2258.description: The application of information technology to chemistry in biological research environment.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0607.label: Laboratory information management
http://edamontology.org/topic_0607.description: Laboratory management and resources, for example, catalogues of biological resources for use in the lab including cell lines, viruses, plasmids, phages, DNA probes and primers and so on.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0091.label: Bioinformatics
http://edamontology.org/topic_0091.description: The archival, curation, processing and analysis of complex biological data.|This includes data  processing in general, including basic handling of files and databases, datatypes, workflows and annotation.

http://edamontology.org/topic_0089.label: Ontology and terminology
http://edamontology.org/topic_0089.description: The conceptualisation, categorisation and nomenclature (naming) of entities or phenomena within biology or bioinformatics. This includes formal ontologies, controlled vocabularies, structured glossary, symbols and terminology or other related resource.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0004.label: Operation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0004.description: A function that processes a set of inputs and results in a set of outputs, or associates arguments (inputs) with values (outputs).|Special cases are: a) An operation that consumes no input (has no input arguments). Such operation is either a constant function, or an operation depending only on the underlying state. b) An operation that may modify the underlying state but has no output. c) The singular-case operation with no input or output, that still may modify the underlying state.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3799.label: Quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3799.description: Counting and measuring experimentally determined observations into quantities.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3800.label: RNA-Seq quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3800.description: Quantification of data arising from RNA-Seq high-throughput sequencing, typically the quantification of transcript abundances durnig transcriptome analysis in a gene expression study.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3630.label: Protein quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3630.description: Technique for determining the amount of proteins in a sample.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3636.label: MRM/SRM
http://edamontology.org/operation_3636.description: Quantification by Selected/multiple Reaction Monitoring workflow (XIC quantitation of precursor / fragment mass pair).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.label: Labeled quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.description: Quantification based on the use of chemical tags.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3715.label: Metabolic labeling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3715.description: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.|This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3705.label: Isotope-coded protein label
http://edamontology.org/operation_3705.description: Chemical tagging free amino groups of intact proteins with stable isotopes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3642.label: Dimethyl
http://edamontology.org/operation_3642.description: Quantification analysis using chemical labeling by stable isotope dimethylation

http://edamontology.org/operation_3641.label: TMT-tag
http://edamontology.org/operation_3641.description: Quantification analysis using the Thermo Fisher tandem mass tag labelling workflow.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3640.label: 18O labeling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3640.description: Quantification analysis using labeling based on 18O-enriched H2O.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3639.label: iTRAQ
http://edamontology.org/operation_3639.description: Quantification analysis using the AB SCIEX iTRAQ isobaric labelling workflow, wherein 2-8 reporter ions are measured in MS2 spectra near 114 m/z.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3638.label: SILAC
http://edamontology.org/operation_3638.description: Quantification analysis using stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.label: Label-free quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.description: Quantification without the use of chemical tags.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3704.label: Ion counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3704.description: Label-free quantification by integration of ion current (ion counting).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3637.label: Spectral counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3637.description: Calculate number of identified MS2 spectra as approximation of peptide / protein quantity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3760.label: Service management
http://edamontology.org/operation_3760.description: Operations concerning the handling and use of other tools.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3763.label: Service invocation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3763.description: An operation supporting the calling (invocation) of other tools and services.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3762.label: Service composition
http://edamontology.org/operation_3762.description: An operation supporting the aggregation of other services (at least two) into a funtional unit, for the automation of some task.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3761.label: Service discovery
http://edamontology.org/operation_3761.description: An operation supporting the browsing or discovery of other tools and services.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3465.label: Correlation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3465.description: Identify a correlation, i.e. a statistical relationship between two random variables or two sets of data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3463.label: Gene expression correlation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3463.description: Analyse the correlation patterns among genes across across a variety of experiments, microarray samples etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0449.label: Sequence alignment analysis (site correlation)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0449.description: Analyse correlations between sites in a molecular sequence alignment.|This is typically done to identify possible covarying positions and predict contacts or structural constraints in protein structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3438.label: Calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3438.description: Mathematical determination of the value of something, typically a properly of a  molecule.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3797.label: Rarefaction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3797.description: The calculation of species richness for a number of individual samples, based on plots of the number of species as a function of the number of samples (rarefaction curves).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3633.label: Retention time prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3633.description: Prediction of retention time in a mass spectrometry experiment based on compositional and structural properties of the separated species.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3632.label: Isotopic distributions calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3632.description: Calculate the isotope distribution of a given chemical species.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2238.label: Statistical calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2238.description: Perform a statistical data operation of some type, e.g. calibration or validation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3664.label: Statistical modelling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3664.description: Construction of a statistical model, or a set of assumptions around some observed data, usually by describing a set of probability distributions which approximate the distribution of data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3659.label: Regression analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3659.description: A statistical calculation to estimate the relationships among variables.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3658.label: Statistical inference
http://edamontology.org/operation_3658.description: Analyse data in order to deduce properties of an underlying distribution or population.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3557.label: Imputation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3557.description: Replace missing data with substituted values, usually by using some statistical or other mathematical approach.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3435.label: Standardisation and normalisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3435.description: Standardize or normalize data by some statistical method.| In the simplest normalisation means adjusting values measured on different scales to a common scale (often between 0.0 and 1.0), but can refer to more sophisticated adjustment whereby entire probability distributions of adjusted values are brought into alignment. Standardisation typically refers to an operation whereby a range of values are standardised to measure how many standard deviations a value is from its mean.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0262.label: Nucleic acid property calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0262.description: Calculate or predict physical or chemical properties of nucleic acid molecules, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0461.label: Nucleic acid curvature calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0461.description: Calculate curvature and flexibility / stiffness of a nucleotide sequence.|This includes properties such as.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0456.label: Nucleic acid melting profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0456.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting profile.|A melting profile is used to visualise and analyse partly melted DNA conformations.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0460.label: Nucleic acid temperature profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0460.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0459.label: Nucleic acid probability profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0459.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA probability profile.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0458.label: Nucleic acid melting curve plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0458.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting curve.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0457.label: Nucleic acid stitch profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0457.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA stitch profile.|A stitch profile represents the alternative conformations that partly melted DNA can adopt in a temperature range.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0455.label: Nucleic acid thermodynamic property calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0455.description: Calculate a thermodynamic property of DNA or DNA/RNA, such as melting temperature, enthalpy and entropy.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0365.label: Nucleic acid restriction digest
http://edamontology.org/operation_0365.description: Generate digest fragments for a nucleotide sequence containing restriction sites.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0250.label: Protein property calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0250.description: Extract, calculate or predict non-positional (physical or chemical) properties of a protein, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence, from processing a protein sequence or 3D structure.|This includes methods to render and visualise the properties of a protein sequence, and a residue-level search for properties such as solvent accessibility, hydropathy, secondary structure, ligand-binding etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2574.label: Protein hydropathy calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2574.description: Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein (from analysis of sequence or structural information).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0410.label: Protein crystallizability prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0410.description: Predict crystallizability of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0409.label: Protein solubility prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0409.description: Predict the solubility or atomic solvation energy of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0408.label: Protein globularity prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0408.description: Predict the stability or globularity of a protein sequence, whether it is intrinsically unfolded etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0407.label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0407.description: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.|Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0406.label: Protein aliphatic index calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0406.description: Calculate aliphatic index (relative volume occupied by aliphatic side chains) of a protein.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0405.label: Protein hydrophobic region calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0405.description: Calculate hydrophobic or hydrophilic / charged regions of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2239.label: 3D-1D scoring matrix generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2239.description: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.|A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0400.label: Protein pKa calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0400.description: Calculate pH-dependent properties from pKa calculations of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0404.label: Protein hydrogen exchange rate calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0404.description: Estimate hydrogen exchange rate of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0403.label: Protein isoelectric point calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0403.description: Calculate isoelectric point of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0399.label: Protein extinction coefficient calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0399.description: Predict extinction coefficients or optical density of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0398.label: Protein molecular weight calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0398.description: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein sequence or fragments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2929.label: Protein fragment weight comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2929.description: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0386.label: Protein dipole moment calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0386.description: Calculate whether a protein structure has an unusually large net charge (dipole moment).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0334.label: Enzyme kinetics calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0334.description: Calculate Km, Vmax and derived data for an enzyme reaction.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0272.label: Residue interaction prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0272.description: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.|Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0252.label: Peptide immunogenicity prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0252.description: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.|This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.|This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0249.label: Protein geometry calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0249.description: Calculate, visualise or analyse phi/psi angles of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0396.label: Ramachandran plot calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0396.description: Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.label: Residue interaction calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.description: Calculate or extract inter-atomic, inter-residue or residue-atom contacts, distances and interactions in protein structure(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.label: Residue distance calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.description: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.|This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output.  It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0393.label: Residue cluster calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0393.description: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.|This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0391.label: Protein distance matrix calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0391.description: Calculate a matrix of distance between residues (for example the C-alpha atoms) in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0392.label: Protein contact map calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0392.description: Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1839.label: Salt bridge calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_1839.description: Calculate (and possibly score) salt bridges in a protein structure.|Salt bridges are interactions between oppositely charged atoms in different residues. The output might include the inter-atomic distance.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1834.label: Protein-metal contact calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_1834.description: Calculate protein residue contacts with metal in a structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1831.label: Metal-bound cysteine detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1831.description: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0394.label: Hydrogen bond calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0394.description: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acids and other groups.|The output might include the atoms involved in the bond, bond geometric parameters and bond enthalpy.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0244.label: Protein flexibility and motion analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0244.description: Analyse flexibility and motion in protein structure.|Use this concept for analysis of flexible and rigid residues, local chain deformability, regions undergoing conformational change, molecular vibrations or fluctuational dynamics, domain motions or other large-scale structural transitions in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0236.label: Sequence composition calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0236.description: Calculate character or word composition or frequency of a molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3472.label: k-mer counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3472.description: Count k-mers (substrings of length k) in DNA sequence data.|k-mer counting is used in genome and transcriptome assembly, metagenomic sequencing, and for error correction of sequence reads.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2284.label: Nucleic acid density plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_2284.description: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0380.label: Repeat sequence organisation analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0380.description: Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0235.label: Sequence ambiguity calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0235.description: Calculate sequence ambiguity, for example identity regions in protein or nucleotide sequences with many ambiguity codes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0234.label: Sequence complexity calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0234.description: Calculate sequence complexity, for example to find low-complexity regions in sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3434.label: Conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_3434.description: Convert a data set from one form to another.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3267.label: Sequence coordinate conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_3267.description: Convert one set of sequence coordinates to another, e.g. convert coordinates of one assembly to another, cDNA to genomic, CDS to genomic, protein translation to genomic etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0260.label: Sequence alignment conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_0260.description: Convert a molecular sequence alignment from one type to another (for example amino acid to coding nucleotide sequence).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0233.label: Sequence conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_0233.description: Convert a molecular sequence from one type to another.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2510.label: DNA back-translation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2510.description: Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0372.label: DNA transcription
http://edamontology.org/operation_0372.description: Transcribe a nucleotide sequence into mRNA sequence(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0371.label: DNA translation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0371.description: Translate a DNA sequence into protein.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3432.label: Clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3432.description: Group together some data entities on the basis of similarities such that entities in the same group (cluster) are more similar to each other than to those in other groups (clusters).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3279.label: Document clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3279.description: Cluster (group) documents on the basis of their calculated similarity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0313.label: Gene expression clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_0313.description: Perform cluster analysis of gene expression data to identify groups with similar gene-expression profiles, for example by clustering.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.label: Sequence clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.description: Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.|The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3459.label: Functional clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3459.description: Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3429.label: Generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3429.description: Construct some data entity.|For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3480.label: Probabilistic data generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3480.description: Generate some data from a choosen probibalistic model, possibly to evaluate algorithms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3481.label: Probabilistic sequence generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3481.description: Generate sequences from some probabilistic model, e.g. a model that simulates evolution.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3469.label: RNA structure covariance model generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3469.description: Compute the covariance model for (a family of) RNA secondary structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3349.label: Bibliography generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3349.description: Construct a bibliography from the scientific literature.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3348.label: Sequence checksum generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3348.description: Generate a checksum of a molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3216.label: Scaffolding
http://edamontology.org/operation_3216.description: Link together a non-contiguous series of genomic sequences into a scaffold, consisting of sequences separated by gaps of known length.  The sequences that are linked are typically typically contigs; contiguous sequences corresponding to read overlaps.|Scaffold may be positioned along a chromosome physical map to create a "golden path".

http://edamontology.org/operation_3217.label: Scaffold gap completion
http://edamontology.org/operation_3217.description: Fill the gaps in a sequence assembly (scaffold) by merging in additional sequences.|Different techniques are used to generate gap sequences to connect contigs, depending on the size of the gap. For small (5-20kb) gaps, PCR amplification and sequencing is used.  For large (>20kb) gaps, fragments are cloned (e.g. in BAC (Bacterial artificial chromosomes) vectors) and then sequenced.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2928.label: Alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_2928.description: Compare two or more entities, typically the sequence or structure (or derivatives) of macromolecules, to identify equivalent subunits.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0303.label: Protein fold recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_0303.description: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.|Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0302.label: Protein threading
http://edamontology.org/operation_0302.description: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).|Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0510.label: Global structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0510.description: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.|Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0509.label: Local structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0509.description: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.|Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0504.label: Multiple structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0504.description: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.|This includes methods that use an existing alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0503.label: Pairwise structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0503.description: Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0292.label: Sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0292.description: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3198.label: Read mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3198.description: Align short oligonucleotide sequences (reads) to a larger (genomic) sequence.|The purpose of read mapping is to identify the location of sequenced fragments within a reference genome and assumes that there is, in fact, at least local similarity between the fragment and reference sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3199.label: Split read mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3199.description: A varient of oligonucleotide mapping where a read is mapped to two separate locations because of possible structural variation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3182.label: Genome alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_3182.description: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.

synonyms: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0499.label: Tree-based sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0499.description: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.|This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0496.label: Global alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0496.description: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.|Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0495.label: Local alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0495.description: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.|Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0492.label: Multiple sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0492.description: Align more than two molecular sequences.|This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0491.label: Pairwise sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0491.description: Align exactly two molecular sequences.|Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0300.label: Sequence profile alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0300.description: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.|A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0294.label: Structure-based sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0294.description: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2239.label: 3D-1D scoring matrix generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2239.description: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.|A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0531.label: Heat map generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0531.description: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.|The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0323.label: Phylogenetic tree generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0323.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree.|Phylogenetic trees are usually constructed from a set of sequences from which an alignment (or data matrix) is calculated.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3478.label: Phylogenetic tree reconstruction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3478.description: Reconstructing the inner node labels of a phylogenetic tree from its leafes.|Note that this is somewhat different from simply analysing an existing tree or constructing a completely new one.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0555.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (consensus)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0555.description: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.|Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0539.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (method centric)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0539.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree using a specific method.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0549.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (AI methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0549.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0548.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (quartet methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0548.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing four-taxon trees (4-trees) and searching for the phylogeny that matches most closely.

synonyms: Phylogenetic tree construction (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0547.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0547.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by relating sequence data to a hypothetical tree topology using a model of sequence evolution.|Maximum likelihood methods search for a tree that maximizes a likelihood function, i.e. that is most likely given the data and model. Bayesian analysis estimate the probability of tree for branch lengths and topology, typically using a Monte Carlo algorithm.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0546.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (minimum distance methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0546.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing (or using precomputed) distances between sequences and searching for the tree with minimal discrepancies between pairwise distances.|This includes neighbor joining (NJ) clustering method.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0545.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (parsimony methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0545.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing a sequence alignment and searching for the tree with the fewest number of character-state changes from the alignment.|This includes evolutionary parsimony (invariants) methods.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0538.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (data centric)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0538.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree from a specific type of data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0543.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from polymorphism data)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0543.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from polymorphism data including microsatellites, RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), RAPD (random-amplified polymorphic DNA) and AFLP (amplified fragment length polymorphisms) data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0542.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from gene frequencies)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0542.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from gene frequency data.

synonyms: Phylogenetic tree construction (from continuous quantitative characters)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0541.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from continuous quantitative characters)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0541.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from continuous quantitative character data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0540.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from molecular sequences)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0540.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.|Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0544.label: Phylogenetic species tree construction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0544.description: Construct a phylogenetic species tree, for example, from a genome-wide sequence comparison.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0327.label: Phylogenetic footprinting / shadowing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0327.description: Infer a phylogenetic tree by comparing orthologous sequences in different species, particularly many closely related species (phylogenetic shadowing).|A phylogenetic 'shadow' represents the additive differences between individual sequences. By masking or 'shadowing' variable positions a conserved sequence is produced with few or none of the variations, which is then compared to the sequences of interest to identify significant regions of conservation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0314.label: Gene expression profiling
http://edamontology.org/operation_0314.description: The measurement of the gene expression of multiple genes in a cell, tissue, sample etc., in order to get an impression of biological function.|Metagenomic inference is the profiling of phylogenetic marker genes in order to predict metagenome function.|Gene expression profiling generates some sort of gene expression profile, for example from microarray data.

synonyms: Gene expression quantitative trait loci profiling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3232.label: Gene expression QTL analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3232.description: Combine classical quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis with gene expression profiling, for example, to describe describe cis- and trans-controlling elements for the expression of phenotype associated genes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0297.label: 3D profile generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0297.description: Generate some type of structural (3D) profile or template from a structure or structure alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0296.label: Sequence profile generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0296.description: Generate some type of sequence profile (for example a hidden Markov model) from a sequence alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.label: Sequence clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.description: Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.|The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3459.label: Functional clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3459.description: Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0289.label: Sequence distance matrix generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0289.description: Calculate a sequence distance matrix or otherwise estimate genetic distances between molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0284.label: Codon usage table generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0284.description: Calculate codon usage statistics and create a codon usage table.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0282.label: Genetic mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0282.description: Generate a genetic (linkage) map of a DNA sequence (typically a chromosome) showing the relative positions of genetic markers based on estimation of non-physical distances.|Mapping involves ordering genetic loci along a chromosome and estimating the physical distance between loci. A genetic map shows the relative (not physical) position of known genes and genetic markers.|This includes mapping of the genetic architecture of dynamic complex traits (functional mapping), e.g. by characterisation of the underlying quantitative trait loci (QTLs) or nucleotides (QTNs).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0487.label: Haplotype mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0487.description: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.|Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. Haplotype comparison is a useful way to characterize the genetic variation between individuals. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. Tools might use combinatorial functions (for example parsimony) or a likelihood function or model with optimisation such as minimum error correction (MEC) model, expectation-maximisation algorithm (EM), genetic algorithm or Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0230.label: Sequence generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0230.description: Generate a molecular sequence by some means.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3481.label: Probabilistic sequence generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3481.description: Generate sequences from some probabilistic model, e.g. a model that simulates evolution.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2514.label: Sequence generation (protein)
http://edamontology.org/operation_2514.description: Generate a protein sequence by some means.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3644.label: de Novo sequencing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3644.description: Analytical process that derives a peptides amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0366.label: Protein sequence cleavage
http://edamontology.org/operation_0366.description: Cleave a protein sequence into peptide fragments (corresponding to enzymatic or chemical cleavage).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2513.label: Sequence generation (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/operation_2513.description: Generate a nucleic acid sequence by some means.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3185.label: Base-calling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3185.description: Identify base (nucleobase) sequence from a fluorescence 'trace' data generated by an automated DNA sequencer.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0365.label: Nucleic acid restriction digest
http://edamontology.org/operation_0365.description: Generate digest fragments for a nucleotide sequence containing restriction sites.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0363.label: Nucleic acid sequence reverse and complement
http://edamontology.org/operation_0363.description: Generate the reverse and / or complement of a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0364.label: Random sequence generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0364.description: Generate a random sequence, for example, with a specific character composition.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2990.label: Classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2990.description: Assign molecular sequences, structures or other biological data to a specific group or category according to qualities it shares with that group or category.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3458.label: Single particle alignment and classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3458.description: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle. |A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2996.label: Structure classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2996.description: Assign molecular structure(s) to a group or category.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2475.label: Protein architecture recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_2475.description: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.|Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2995.label: Sequence classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2995.description: Assign molecular sequence(s) to a group or category.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3460.label: Taxonomic classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3460.description: Classifiication (typically of molecular sequences) by assignment to some taxonomic hierarchy.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3225.label: Variant classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3225.description: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.|Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)

http://edamontology.org/operation_2945.label: Analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2945.description: Apply analytical methods to existing data of a specific type.|This excludes non-analytical methods that read and write the same basic type of data (for that, see 'Data handling').

http://edamontology.org/operation_3501.label: Enrichment analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3501.description: Analysis of a set of objects, such as genes, annotated with given categories, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain categories within the studied set of objects is revealed.|Categories from a relevant ontology can be used. The input is typically a set of genes or other biological objects, possibly represented by their identifiers, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of categories, each associated with a statistical metric of over-/under-representation within the studied data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3502.label: Chemical similarity enrichment
http://edamontology.org/operation_3502.description: Analyse a dataset with respect to concepts from an ontology of chemical structure, leveraging chemical similarity information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2436.label: Gene-set enrichment analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2436.description: Analysis of a set of genes, corresponding e.g. to a gene expression profile, annotated with Gene Ontology (GO) concepts, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain GO concept within the studied set of genes is revealed.|The Gene Ontology (GO) is typically used, the input is a set of Gene IDs, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of GO concepts, each associated with a p-value.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3443.label: Image analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3443.description: The analysis of a image (typically a digital image) of some type in order to extract information from it.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3457.label: Single particle analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3457.description: An image processing technique that combines and analyze multiple images of a particulate sample, in order to produce an image with clearer features that are more easily interpreted.|Single particle analysis is used to improve the information that can be obtained by relatively low resolution techniques, , e.g. an image of a protein or virus from transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3458.label: Single particle alignment and classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3458.description: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle. |A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3450.label: Neurite measurement
http://edamontology.org/operation_3450.description: Measurement of neurites; projections (axons or dendrites) from the cell body of a neuron, from analysis of neuron images.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3446.label: Cell migration analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3446.description: Analysis of cell migration images in order to study cell migration, typically in order to study the processes that play a role in the disease progression.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3214.label: Spectral analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3214.description: Analyse one or more spectra from mass spectrometry (or other) experiments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3803.label: Natural product identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3803.description: Mass spectra identification of compounds that are produced by living systems. Including polyketides, terpenoids, phenylpropanoids, alkaloids and antibiotics.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3767.label: Protein identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3767.description: Identification of protein, for example from one or more peptide identifications by tandem mass spectrometry.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3631.label: Peptide identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3631.description: Determination of peptide sequence from mass spectrum.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3801.label: Spectral library search
http://edamontology.org/operation_3801.description: Match experimentally measured mass spectrum to a spectrum in a spectral library or database.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3646.label: Peptide database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_3646.description: Determination of best matches between MS/MS spectrum and a database of protein or nucleic acid sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3649.label: Target-Decoy
http://edamontology.org/operation_3649.description: Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3647.label: Blind peptide database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_3647.description: Peptide database search for identification of known and unknown PTMs looking for mass difference mismatches.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3645.label: PTM identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3645.description: Identification of post-translational modifications (PTMs) of peptides/proteins in mass spectrum.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3755.label: PTM localisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3755.description: Site localisation of post-translational modifications in peptide or protein mass spectra.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3644.label: de Novo sequencing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3644.description: Analytical process that derives a peptides amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3643.label: Tag-based peptide identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3643.description: Peptide sequence tags are used as piece of information about a peptide obtained by tandem mass spectrometry.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3630.label: Protein quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3630.description: Technique for determining the amount of proteins in a sample.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3636.label: MRM/SRM
http://edamontology.org/operation_3636.description: Quantification by Selected/multiple Reaction Monitoring workflow (XIC quantitation of precursor / fragment mass pair).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.label: Labeled quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.description: Quantification based on the use of chemical tags.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3715.label: Metabolic labeling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3715.description: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.|This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3705.label: Isotope-coded protein label
http://edamontology.org/operation_3705.description: Chemical tagging free amino groups of intact proteins with stable isotopes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3642.label: Dimethyl
http://edamontology.org/operation_3642.description: Quantification analysis using chemical labeling by stable isotope dimethylation

http://edamontology.org/operation_3641.label: TMT-tag
http://edamontology.org/operation_3641.description: Quantification analysis using the Thermo Fisher tandem mass tag labelling workflow.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3640.label: 18O labeling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3640.description: Quantification analysis using labeling based on 18O-enriched H2O.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3639.label: iTRAQ
http://edamontology.org/operation_3639.description: Quantification analysis using the AB SCIEX iTRAQ isobaric labelling workflow, wherein 2-8 reporter ions are measured in MS2 spectra near 114 m/z.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3638.label: SILAC
http://edamontology.org/operation_3638.description: Quantification analysis using stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.label: Label-free quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.description: Quantification without the use of chemical tags.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3704.label: Ion counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3704.description: Label-free quantification by integration of ion current (ion counting).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3637.label: Spectral counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3637.description: Calculate number of identified MS2 spectra as approximation of peptide / protein quantity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3629.label: Deisotoping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3629.description: The removal of isotope peaks in a spectrum, to represent the fragment ion as one data point.|Deisotoping is commonly done to reduce complexity, and done in conjunction with the charge state deconvolution.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3628.label: Chromatographic alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_3628.description: Align multiple data sets using information from chromatography and/or peptide identification, from mass spectrometry experiments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3627.label: Mass spectra calibration
http://edamontology.org/operation_3627.description: Re-adjust the output of mass spectrometry experiments with shifted ppm values.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3215.label: Peak detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3215.description: Identify peaks in a spectrum from a mass spectrometry, NMR, or some other spectrum-generating experiment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3197.label: Genetic variation analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3197.description: Analyse a genetic variation, for example to annotate its location, alleles, classification, and effects on individual transcripts predicted for a gene model.|Genetic variation annotation provides contextual interpretation of coding SNP consequences in transcripts. It allows comparisons to be made between variation data in different populations or strains for the same transcript.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3791.label: Collapsing methods
http://edamontology.org/operation_3791.description: A method whereby data on several variants are "collapsed" into a single covariate based on regions such as genes.|Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) analyse a genome-wide set of genetic variants in different individuals to see if any variant is associated with a trait. Traditional association techniques can lack the power to detect the significance of rare variants individually, or measure their compound effect (rare variant burden).  "Collapsing methods" were developed to overcome these problems.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3703.label: Reference identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3703.description: Identification of the best reference for mapping for a specific dataset from a list of potential references, when performing genetic variation analysis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3504.label: Variant pattern analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3504.description: Identify and map patterns of genomic variations.|Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3228.label: Structural variation detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3228.description: Detect large regions in a genome subject to copy-number variation, or other structural variations in genome(s).|Methods might involve analysis of whole-genome array comparative genome hybridisation or single-nucleotide polymorphism arrays, paired-end mapping of sequencing data, or from analysis of short reads from new sequencing technologies.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3226.label: Variant prioritisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3226.description: Identify biologically interesting variants by prioritizing individual variants, for example, homozygous variants absent in control genomes.|Variant prioritisation can be used for example to produce a list of variants responsible for 'knocking out' genes in specific genomes. Methods amino acid substitution, aggregative approaches, probabilistic approach, inheritance and unified likelihood-frameworks.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3225.label: Variant classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3225.description: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.|Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)

http://edamontology.org/operation_3202.label: Polymorphism detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3202.description: Detect mutations in multiple DNA sequences, for example, from the alignment and comparison of the fluorescent traces produced by DNA sequencing hardware.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3227.label: Variant calling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3227.description: Identify and map genomic alterations, including single nucleotide polymorphisms, short indels and structural variants, in a genome sequence.|Somatic variant calling is the detection of variations established in somatic cells and hence not inherited as a germ line variant.|Variant detection|Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0484.label: SNP detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0484.description: Find single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) - single nucleotide change in base positions - between sequences. Typically done for sequences from a high-throughput sequencing experiment that differ from a reference genome and which might, especially by reference to population frequency or functional data, indicate a polymorphism.|This includes functional SNPs for large-scale genotyping purposes, disease-associated non-synonymous SNPs etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0452.label: Indel detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0452.description: Identify insertion, deletion and duplication events from a sequence alignment.|Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0265.label: Frameshift detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0265.description: Detect frameshifts in DNA sequences, including frameshift sites and signals, and frameshift errors from sequencing projects.|Methods include sequence alignment (if related sequences are available) and word-based sequence comparison.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3196.label: Genotyping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3196.description: Analyse DNA sequence data to identify differences between the genetic composition (genotype) of an individual compared to other individual's or a reference sequence.|Methods might consider cytogenetic analyses, copy number polymorphism (and calculate copy number calls for copy-number variation(CNV) regions), single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), , rare copy number variation (CNV) identification, loss of heterozygosity data and so on.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2497.label: Pathway or network analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2497.description: Generate, process or analyse a biological pathway or network.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3766.label: Weighted correlation network analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3766.description: A data mining method typically used for studying biological networks based on pairwise correlations between variables.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3439.label: Pathway or network prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3439.description: Predict a molecular pathway or network.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3083.label: Pathway or network visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3083.description: Render (visualise) a biological pathway or network.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1781.label: Gene regulatory network analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_1781.description: Analyse a known network of gene regulation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0533.label: Gene to pathway mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0533.description: Map a gene expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0277.label: Pathway or network comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0277.description: Compare two or more biological pathways or networks.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0276.label: Protein interaction network analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0276.description: Analyse a network of protein interactions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2495.label: Gene expression analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2495.description: The application of bioinformatics methods to the study of gene products, typically by processing gene expression data or profiles, interpreting them in functional terms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3792.label: miRNA expression analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3792.description: The analysis of microRNAs (miRNAs) : short, highly conserved small noncoding RNA molecules that are naturally occurring plant and animal genomes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3224.label: Gene set testing
