http://edamontology.org/operation_0443.description: Identify or predict functional RNA sequences with a gene regulatory role (trans-regulatory elements) or targets.|Trans-regulatory elements regulate genes distant from the gene from which they were transcribed.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2008.label: siRNA duplex prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_2008.description: Identify or predict siRNA duplexes in RNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0465.label: siRNA binding specificity prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0465.description: Assess binding specificity of putative siRNA sequence(s), for example for a functional assay, typically with respect to designing specific siRNA sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0463.label: microRNA detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0463.description: Identify or predict microRNA sequences (miRNA) and precursors or microRNA targets / binding sites in a DNA sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0441.label: cis-regulatory element prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0441.description: Identify, predict or analyse cis-regulatory elements  in DNA sequences (TATA box, Pribnow box, SOS box, CAAT box, CCAAT box, operator etc.) or in RNA sequences (e.g. riboswitches).|Cis-regulatory elements (cis-elements) regulate the expression of genes located on the same strand from which the element was transcribed. Cis-elements are found in the 5' promoter region of the gene, in an intron, or in the 3' untranslated region. Cis-elements are often binding sites of one or more trans-acting factors. They also occur in RNA sequences, e.g. a riboswitch is a region of an mRNA molecule that bind a small target molecule that regulates the gene's activity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0440.label: Promoter prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0440.description: Identify or predict whole promoters or promoter elements (transcription start sites, RNA polymerase binding site, transcription factor binding sites, promoter enhancers etc) in DNA sequences.|Methods might recognize CG content, CpG islands, splice sites, polyA signals etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0446.label: Exonic splicing enhancer prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0446.description: Identify or predict exonic splicing enhancers (ESE) in exons.|An exonic splicing enhancer (ESE) is 6-base DNA sequence motif in an exon that enhances or directs splicing of pre-mRNA or hetero-nuclear RNA (hnRNA) into mRNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0445.label: Transcription factor binding site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0445.description: Identify or predict transcription factor binding sites in DNA sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0437.label: SECIS element prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0437.description: Predict selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in a DNA sequence.|SECIS elements are around 60 nucleotides in length with a stem-loop structure directs the cell to translate UGA codons as selenocysteines.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0436.label: Coding region prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0436.description: Predict protein-coding regions (CDS or exon) or open reading frames in nucleotide sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0439.label: Translation initiation site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0439.description: Predict translation initiation sites, possibly by searching a database of sites.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0435.label: Operon prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0435.description: Find operons (operators, promoters and genes) in bacteria genes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0433.label: Splice site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0433.description: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.|Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0432.label: Nucleosome formation or exclusion sequence prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0432.description: Identify or predict nucleosome exclusion sequences (nucleosome free regions) in DNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0431.label: Restriction site recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_0431.description: Find and identify restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in (typically) DNA sequences, for example to generate a restriction map.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0430.label: CpG island and isochore detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0430.description: Find CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence or isochores in genome sequences.|An isochore is long region (> 3 KB) of DNA with very uniform GC content, in contrast to the rest of the genome. Isochores tend tends to have more genes, higher local melting or denaturation temperatures, and different flexibility. Methods might calculate fractional GC content or variation of GC content, predict methylation status of CpG islands etc. This includes methods that visualise CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence, for example plot isochores in a genome sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0429.label: Quadruplex formation site detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0429.description: Detect quadruplex-forming motifs in nucleotide sequences.|Quadruplex (4-stranded) structures are formed by guanine-rich regions and are implicated in various important biological processes and as therapeutic targets.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0428.label: PolyA signal detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0428.description: Detect polyA signals in nucleotide sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0427.label: Transposon prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0427.description: Detect or predict transposons, retrotransposons / retrotransposition signatures etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0379.label: Repeat sequence detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0379.description: Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0278.label: RNA secondary structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0278.description: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).|Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0266.label: Vector sequence detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0266.description: Detect vector sequences in nucleotide sequence, typically by comparison to a set of known vector sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0320.label: Protein structure assignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0320.description: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1850.label: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_1850.description: Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1831.label: Metal-bound cysteine detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1831.description: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1830.label: Free cysteine detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1830.description: Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.|A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1829.label: Cysteine bridge detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1829.description: Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0319.label: Protein secondary structure assignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0319.description: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0306.label: Text mining
http://edamontology.org/operation_0306.description: Process and analyse text (typically scientific literature) to extract information from it.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3625.label: Relation extraction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3625.description: Identify semantic relations among entities and concepts within a text, using text mining techniques.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3280.label: Named-entity and concept recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_3280.description: Recognise named entities, ontology concepts, tags, events, and dictionary terms within documents.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0267.label: Protein secondary structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0267.description: Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.|Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0470.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (coils)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0470.description: Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0469.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (turns)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0469.description: Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0468.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (helices)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0468.description: Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0269.label: Transmembrane protein prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0269.description: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0268.label: Protein super-secondary structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0268.description: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).|Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0253.label: Sequence feature detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0253.description: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.|Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0239.label: Sequence motif recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_0239.description: Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0238.label: Sequence motif discovery
http://edamontology.org/operation_0238.description: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).|Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0250.label: Protein property calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0250.description: Extract, calculate or predict non-positional (physical or chemical) properties of a protein, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence, from processing a protein sequence or 3D structure.|This includes methods to render and visualise the properties of a protein sequence, and a residue-level search for properties such as solvent accessibility, hydropathy, secondary structure, ligand-binding etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2574.label: Protein hydropathy calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2574.description: Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein (from analysis of sequence or structural information).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0410.label: Protein crystallizability prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0410.description: Predict crystallizability of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0409.label: Protein solubility prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0409.description: Predict the solubility or atomic solvation energy of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0408.label: Protein globularity prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0408.description: Predict the stability or globularity of a protein sequence, whether it is intrinsically unfolded etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0407.label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0407.description: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.|Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0406.label: Protein aliphatic index calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0406.description: Calculate aliphatic index (relative volume occupied by aliphatic side chains) of a protein.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0405.label: Protein hydrophobic region calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0405.description: Calculate hydrophobic or hydrophilic / charged regions of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2239.label: 3D-1D scoring matrix generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2239.description: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.|A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0400.label: Protein pKa calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0400.description: Calculate pH-dependent properties from pKa calculations of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0404.label: Protein hydrogen exchange rate calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0404.description: Estimate hydrogen exchange rate of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0403.label: Protein isoelectric point calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0403.description: Calculate isoelectric point of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0399.label: Protein extinction coefficient calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0399.description: Predict extinction coefficients or optical density of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0398.label: Protein molecular weight calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0398.description: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein sequence or fragments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2929.label: Protein fragment weight comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2929.description: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0386.label: Protein dipole moment calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0386.description: Calculate whether a protein structure has an unusually large net charge (dipole moment).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0334.label: Enzyme kinetics calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0334.description: Calculate Km, Vmax and derived data for an enzyme reaction.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0272.label: Residue interaction prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0272.description: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.|Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0252.label: Peptide immunogenicity prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0252.description: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.|This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.|This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0249.label: Protein geometry calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0249.description: Calculate, visualise or analyse phi/psi angles of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0396.label: Ramachandran plot calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0396.description: Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.label: Residue interaction calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.description: Calculate or extract inter-atomic, inter-residue or residue-atom contacts, distances and interactions in protein structure(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.label: Residue distance calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.description: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.|This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output.  It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0393.label: Residue cluster calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0393.description: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.|This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0391.label: Protein distance matrix calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0391.description: Calculate a matrix of distance between residues (for example the C-alpha atoms) in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0392.label: Protein contact map calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0392.description: Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1839.label: Salt bridge calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_1839.description: Calculate (and possibly score) salt bridges in a protein structure.|Salt bridges are interactions between oppositely charged atoms in different residues. The output might include the inter-atomic distance.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1834.label: Protein-metal contact calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_1834.description: Calculate protein residue contacts with metal in a structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1831.label: Metal-bound cysteine detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1831.description: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0394.label: Hydrogen bond calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0394.description: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acids and other groups.|The output might include the atoms involved in the bond, bond geometric parameters and bond enthalpy.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0244.label: Protein flexibility and motion analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0244.description: Analyse flexibility and motion in protein structure.|Use this concept for analysis of flexible and rigid residues, local chain deformability, regions undergoing conformational change, molecular vibrations or fluctuational dynamics, domain motions or other large-scale structural transitions in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2409.label: Data handling
http://edamontology.org/operation_2409.description: Basic (non-analytical) operations of some data, either a file or equivalent entity in memory, such that the same basic type of data is consumed as input and generated as output.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3802.label: Sorting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3802.description: Sort a set of files or data items according to some property.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3695.label: Filtering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3695.description: Filter a set of files or data items according to some property.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3436.label: Aggregation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3436.description: Combine multiple files or data items into a single file or object.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3431.label: Deposition
http://edamontology.org/operation_3431.description: Deposit some data in a database or some other type of repository or software system.|For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3359.label: Splitting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3359.description: Split a file containing multiple data items into many files, each containing one item

http://edamontology.org/operation_3357.label: Format detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3357.description: Recognition of which format the given data is in.|'Format recognition' is not a bioinformatics-specific operation, but of great relevance in bioinformatics. Should be removed from EDAM if/when captured satisfactorily in a suitable domain-generic ontology.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3283.label: Anonymisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3283.description: Process data in such a way that makes it hard to trace to the person which the data concerns.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3096.label: Editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3096.description: Edit a data entity, either randomly or specifically.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3081.label: Sequence alignment editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3081.description: Edit, convert or otherwise change a molecular sequence alignment, either randomly or specifically.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0260.label: Sequence alignment conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_0260.description: Convert a molecular sequence alignment from one type to another (for example amino acid to coding nucleotide sequence).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3080.label: Structure editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3080.description: Edit, convert or otherwise change a  molecular tertiary structure, either randomly or specifically.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0231.label: Sequence editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0231.description: Edit or change a molecular sequence, either randomly or specifically.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2121.label: Sequence file editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_2121.description: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0370.label: Restriction site creation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0370.description: Create (or remove) restriction sites in sequences, for example using silent mutations.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0369.label: Sequence cutting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0369.description: Cut (remove) characters or a region from a molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3237.label: Primer removal
http://edamontology.org/operation_3237.description: Remove forward and/or reverse primers from nucleic acid sequences (typically PCR products).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3192.label: Sequence trimming
http://edamontology.org/operation_3192.description:
Cut (remove) the end from a molecular sequence.|This includes



ennd trimming

Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove misleading ends.

For example trim polyA tails, introns and primer sequence flanking the sequence of amplified exons, or other unwanted sequence.



trimming to a reference sequence, 

Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove the sequence ends that extend beyond an assembled reference sequence.



vector trimming

Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove sequence-specific end regions, typically contamination from vector sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0368.label: Sequence masking
http://edamontology.org/operation_0368.description: Mask characters in a molecular sequence (replacing those characters with a mask character).|For example, SNPs or repeats in a DNA sequence might be masked.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0367.label: Sequence mutation and randomisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0367.description: Mutate a molecular sequence a specified amount or shuffle it to produce a randomised sequence with the same overall composition.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0233.label: Sequence conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_0233.description: Convert a molecular sequence from one type to another.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2510.label: DNA back-translation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2510.description: Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0372.label: DNA transcription
http://edamontology.org/operation_0372.description: Transcribe a nucleotide sequence into mRNA sequence(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0371.label: DNA translation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0371.description: Translate a DNA sequence into protein.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0232.label: Sequence merging
http://edamontology.org/operation_0232.description: Merge two or more (typically overlapping) molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1812.label: Loading
http://edamontology.org/operation_1812.description: Prepare or load a user-specified data file so that it is available for use.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0335.label: Formatting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0335.description: Reformat a file of data (or equivalent entity in memory).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0224.label: Query and retrieval
http://edamontology.org/operation_0224.description: Search or query a data resource and retrieve entries and / or annotation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2422.label: Data retrieval
http://edamontology.org/operation_2422.description: Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2421.label: Database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_2421.description: Search a database (or other data resource) with a supplied query and retrieve entries (or parts of entries) that are similar to the query.|Typically the query is compared to each entry and high scoring matches (hits) are returned. For example, a BLAST search of a sequence database.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3646.label: Peptide database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_3646.description: Determination of best matches between MS/MS spectrum and a database of protein or nucleic acid sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3649.label: Target-Decoy
http://edamontology.org/operation_3649.description: Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3647.label: Blind peptide database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_3647.description: Peptide database search for identification of known and unknown PTMs looking for mass difference mismatches.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0339.label: Structure database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0339.description: Search a tertiary structure database, typically by sequence and/or structure comparison, or some other means, and retrieve structures and associated data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0360.label: Structural similarity search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0360.description: Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0346.label: Sequence similarity search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0346.description: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0338.label: Sequence database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0338.description:
Search a sequence database by sequence comparison and retrieve similar sequences.

sequences matching a given sequence motif or pattern, such as a Prosite pattern or regular expression.|This excludes direct retrieval methods (e.g. the dbfetch program).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0349.label: Sequence database search (by property)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0349.description: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences with a specified property, typically a physicochemical or compositional property.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0346.label: Sequence similarity search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0346.description: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0305.label: Literature search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0305.description: Query scientific literature, in search for articles, article data, concepts, named entities, or for statistics.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0337.label: Visualisation

http://edamontology.org/operation_0531.label: Heat map generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0531.description: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.|The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0570.label: Structure visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0570.description: Visualise or render molecular structure, for example a high-quality static picture or animation.  This includes secondary structure such as knots, pseudoknots etc. as well as tertiary and quaternary structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2486.description: Render a topology diagram of protein secondary structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2485.label: Helical wheel drawing
http://edamontology.org/operation_2485.description: Render a helical wheel representation of protein secondary structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2241.description: Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1816.description: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.|A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0567.description: Render or visualise a phylogenetic tree.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0566.description: Visualise, format or render sequence clusters.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3208.description: Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3184.label: Sequence assembly visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3184.description: Render and visualise a DNA sequence assembly.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2963.description: Generate a codon usage bias plot.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2284.description: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0490.label: Dot plot plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0490.description: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.|Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0407.label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0407.description: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.|Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0287.label: Base position variability plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0287.description: Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0456.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting profile.|A melting profile is used to visualise and analyse partly melted DNA conformations.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0460.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0459.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA probability profile.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0458.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting curve.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0457.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA stitch profile.|A stitch profile represents the alternative conformations that partly melted DNA can adopt in a temperature range.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0227.label: Indexing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0227.description: Generate an index of (typically a file of) biological data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3211.label: Genome indexing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3211.description: Generate an index of a genome sequence.|Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment.  The Burrows-Wheeler Transform (BWT) is a permutation of the genome based on a suffix array algorithm.  A suffix array consists of the lexicographically sorted list of suffixes of a genome.

http://edamontology.org/format_1915.label: Format
http://edamontology.org/format_1915.description: A defined way or layout of representing and structuring data in a computer file, blob, string, message, or elsewhere.|The main focus in EDAM lies on formats as means of structuring data exchanged between different tools or resources. The serialisation, compression, or encoding of concrete data formats/models is not in scope of EDAM. Format 'is format of' Data.

http://edamontology.org/format_3750.description: YAML (YAML Ain't Markup Language) is a human-readable tree-structured data serialisation language.|Data in YAML format can be serialised into text, or binary format.|YAML version 1.2 is a superset of JSON; prior versions were "not strictly compatible".

http://edamontology.org/format_3607.description: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences).|Phred quality scores  are defined as a property which is logarithmically related to the base-calling error probabilities.

http://edamontology.org/format_3611.label: qual454
http://edamontology.org/format_3611.description: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from 454 sequencers.

http://edamontology.org/format_3610.description: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for SOLiD data.|For SOLiD data, the sequence is in color space, except the first position. The quality values are those of the Sanger format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3609.label: qualillumina
http://edamontology.org/format_3609.description: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.|Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. http://edamontology.org/format_3547.description: Format used for images and image metadata.

http://edamontology.org/format_3727.description: Image file format used by the Open Microscopy Environment (OME).|An OME-TIFF dataset consists of one or more files in standard TIFF or BigTIFF format, with the file extension .ome.tif or .ome.tiff, and an identical (or in the case of multiple files, nearly identical) string of OME-XML metadata embedded in the ImageDescription tag of each files first IFD (Image File Directory). BigTIFF file extensions are also permitted, with the file extension .ome.tf2, .ome.tf8 or .ome.btf, but note these file extensions are an addition to the original specification, and software using an older version of the specification may not be able to handle these file extensions.|OME develops open-source software and data format standards for the storage and manipulation of biological microscopy data. It is a joint project between universities, research establishments, industry and the software development community.

http://edamontology.org/format_3616.description: TAB-delimited genome position file index format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3615.label: bgzip
http://edamontology.org/format_3615.description: Blocked GNU Zip format.|BAM files are compressed using a variant of GZIP (GNU ZIP), into a format called BGZF (Blocked GNU Zip Format).

http://edamontology.org/format_3605.label: rast
http://edamontology.org/format_3605.description: Sun Raster is a raster graphics file format used on SunOS by Sun Microsystems| The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.

http://edamontology.org/format_3604.label: SVG
http://edamontology.org/format_3604.description: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) is an XML-based vector image format for two-dimensional graphics with support for interactivity and animation.| The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.

http://edamontology.org/format_3603.label: PNG
http://edamontology.org/format_3603.description: PNG is a file format for image compression.|It iis expected to replace the Graphics Interchange Format (GIF).

http://edamontology.org/format_3602.label: pgm
http://edamontology.org/format_3602.description: The PGM format is a lowest common denominator grayscale file format.|It is designed to be extremely easy to learn and write programs for.

http://edamontology.org/format_3601.label: pbm
http://edamontology.org/format_3601.description: The PBM format is a lowest common denominator monochrome file format. It serves as the common language of a large family of bitmap image conversion filters.

http://edamontology.org/format_3599.label: xpm

http://edamontology.org/format_3598.label: xbm
http://edamontology.org/format_3598.description: X BitMap is a plain text binary image format used by the X Window System used for storing cursor and icon bitmaps used in the X GUI. |The XBM format was replaced by XPM for X11 in 1989.

http://edamontology.org/format_3597.label: psd
http://edamontology.org/format_3597.description: PSD (Photoshop Document) is a proprietary file that allows the user to work with the images individual layers even after the file has been saved.

http://edamontology.org/format_3596.description: The PPM format is a lowest common denominator color image file format.

Due to it PCD is often used by many photographers and graphics professionals for high-end printed applications.

http://edamontology.org/format_3592.label: bmp
http://edamontology.org/format_3592.description: Standard bitmap storage format in the Microsoft Windows environment.|Although it is based on Windows internal bitmap data structures, it is supported by many non-Windows and non-PC applications.

http://edamontology.org/format_3579.label: JPG
http://edamontology.org/format_3579.description: Joint Picture Group file format for lossy graphics file.|Sequence of segments with markers. Begins with byte of 0xFF and follows by marker type.

http://edamontology.org/format_3551.description: Nearly Raw Rasta Data format designed to support scientific visualisation and image processing involving N-dimensional raster data.

http://edamontology.org/format_3484.description: Bowtie format for indexed reference genome for "small" genomes.

There are also some readers (http://doi.org/10.1021/pr2005154) and converters (http://doi.org/10.1016/j.jprot.2015.06.015) for this format available, which re-engineered the database schema, but there is no official DB schema specification of Thermo Scientific for the format.

This entry is for the metadata XML file

http://edamontology.org/format_3652.description: Spectral data format file where each spectrum is written to a separate file.|Each file contains one header line for the known or assumed charge and the mass of the precursor peptide ion, calculated from the measured *m*/*z* and the charge. The Investigation / Study / Assay (ISA) tab-delimited (TAB) format incorporates metadata from

http://edamontology.org/format_3686.description: Open Modeling EXchange format (OMEX) is a ZIPped format for encapsulating all information necessary for a modeling and simulation project in systems biology.|An OMEX file is a ZIP container that includes a manifest file, listing the content of the archive, an optional metadata file adding information about the archive and its content, and the files describing the model. OMEX is one of the standardised formats within COMBINE (Computational Modeling in Biology Network).

http://edamontology.org/format_3685.label: SED-ML
http://edamontology.org/format_3685.description: Simulation Experiment Description Markup Language (SED-ML) is an XML format for encoding simulation setups, according to the MIASE (Minimum Information About a Simulation Experiment) requirements.

http://edamontology.org/format_3684.label: PRIDE XML
http://edamontology.org/format_3684.description: PRIDE XML is an XML format for mass spectra, peptide and protein identifications, and metadata about a corresponding measurement, sample, experiment.

http://edamontology.org/format_3683.description: qcML is an XML format for quality-related data of mass spectrometry and other high-throughput measurements.|The focus of qcML is towards mass spectrometry based proteomics, but the format is suitable for metabolomics and sequencing as well.

http://edamontology.org/format_3250.label: spML

http://edamontology.org/format_3166.description: Data format for a report of information derived from a biological pathway or network.

http://edamontology.org/format_3239.description: CopasiML, the native format of COPASI.

http://edamontology.org/format_3010.label: .nib

http://edamontology.org/format_2566.label: completely unambiguous
http://edamontology.org/format_2566.description: Alphabet for a molecular sequence without any unknown positions or ambiguity characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_2567.description: Alphabet for a molecular sequence without unknown positions, ambiguity or non-sequence characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_2607.description: Alphabet for any protein sequence without unknown positions, ambiguity or non-sequence characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_2569.description: Alphabet for a DNA sequence (characters ACGT only) without unknown positions, ambiguity or non-sequence characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_2568.description: Alphabet for a nucleotide sequence (characters ACGTU only) without unknown positions, ambiguity or non-sequence characters .

http://edamontology.org/format_2097.label: ambiguous
http://edamontology.org/format_2097.description: Alphabet for a molecular sequence with possible unknown positions and possible ambiguity characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_1209.label: consensus
http://edamontology.org/format_1209.description: Alphabet for the consensus of two or more molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/format_2096.label: unambiguous sequence
http://edamontology.org/format_2096.description: Alphabet for a molecular sequence with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_1206.label: unambiguous pure
http://edamontology.org/format_1206.description: Alphabet for a molecular sequence with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_1218.label: unambiguous pure protein
http://edamontology.org/format_1218.description: Alphabet for any protein sequence with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_1216.description: Alphabet for an RNA sequence (characters ACGU only) with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_1214.label: unambiguous pure dna
http://edamontology.org/format_1214.description: Alphabet for a DNA sequence (characters ACGT only) with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_1211.label: unambiguous pure nucleotide
http://edamontology.org/format_1211.description: Alphabet for a nucleotide sequence (characters ACGTU only) with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters .

http://edamontology.org/format_2095.description: Alphabet for a molecular sequence with possible unknown positions but possibly with non-sequence characters.

http://edamontology.org/format_1336.description: Format of EMBASSY domain hits file (DHF) of hits (sequences) with domain classification information.|The hits are relatives to a SCOP or CATH family and are found from a search of a sequence database.

http://edamontology.org/format_1551.description: Format of output of the Pcons Model Quality Assessment Program (MQAP).|Pcons ranks protein models by assessing their quality based on the occurrence of recurring common three-dimensional structural patterns. Pcons returns a score reflecting the overall global quality and a score for each individual residue in the protein reflecting the local residue quality.

http://edamontology.org/format_3687.label: ISA-TAB
http://edamontology.org/format_3687.description:
The Investigation / Study / Assay (ISA) tab-delimited (TAB) format incorporates metadata from 

experiments employing a combination of technologies.|ISA-TAB is based on MAGE-TAB. Other than tabular, the ISA model can also be represented in RDF, and in JSON (compliable with a set of defined JSON Schemata).

http://edamontology.org/format_3580.label: rcc

http://edamontology.org/format_3578.label: IDAT

http://edamontology.org/format_3727.label: OME-TIFF

OMEX is one of the standardised formats within COMBINE (Computational Modeling in Biology Network).

http://edamontology.org/format_3665.description: A list of k-mers and their occurences in a dataset. Can also be used as an implicit De Bruijn graph.

http://edamontology.org/format_3621.label: SQLite format
http://edamontology.org/format_3621.description: Data format used by the SQLite database.

http://edamontology.org/format_3622.label: Gemini SQLite format
http://edamontology.org/format_3622.description: Data format used by the SQLite database conformant to the Gemini schema.

http://edamontology.org/format_3620.label: xlsx
http://edamontology.org/format_3620.description: MS Excel spreadsheet format consisting of a set of XML documents stored in a ZIP-compressed file.

http://edamontology.org/format_3616.label: tabix
http://edamontology.org/format_3616.description: TAB-delimited genome position file index format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3615.label: bgzip
http://edamontology.org/format_3615.description: Blocked GNU Zip format.|BAM files are compressed using a variant of GZIP (GNU ZIP), into a format called BGZF (Blocked GNU Zip Format).

http://edamontology.org/format_3605.label: rast
http://edamontology.org/format_3605.description: Sun Raster is a raster graphics file format used on SunOS by Sun Microsystems| The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.

http://edamontology.org/format_3603.label: PNG
http://edamontology.org/format_3603.description: PNG is a file format for image compression.|It iis expected to replace the Graphics Interchange Format (GIF).

http://edamontology.org/format_3602.label: pgm
http://edamontology.org/format_3602.description: The PGM format is a lowest common denominator grayscale file format.|It is designed to be extremely easy to learn and write programs for.

http://edamontology.org/format_3601.label: pbm
http://edamontology.org/format_3601.description: The PBM format is a lowest common denominator monochrome file format. It serves as the common language of a large family of bitmap image conversion filters.

http://edamontology.org/format_3600.label: rgb
http://edamontology.org/format_3600.description: RGB file format is the native raster graphics file format for Silicon Graphics workstations.

http://edamontology.org/format_3599.label: xpm
http://edamontology.org/format_3599.description: X PixMap (XPM) is an image file format used by the X Window System, it is intended primarily for creating icon pixmaps, and supports transparent pixels.|Sequence of segments with markers. Begins with byte of 0xFF and follows by marker type.

http://edamontology.org/format_3598.label: xbm
http://edamontology.org/format_3598.description: X BitMap is a plain text binary image format used by the X Window System used for storing cursor and icon bitmaps used in the X GUI. |The XBM format was replaced by XPM for X11 in 1989.

http://edamontology.org/format_3597.label: psd
http://edamontology.org/format_3597.description: PSD (Photoshop Document) is a proprietary file that allows the user to work with the images individual layers even after the file has been saved.

http://edamontology.org/format_3596.label: ppm
http://edamontology.org/format_3596.description: The PPM format is a lowest common denominator color image file format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3595.label: pcx
http://edamontology.org/format_3595.description: PCX is an image file format that uses a simple form of run-length encoding. It is lossless.

http://edamontology.org/format_3594.label: pcd
http://edamontology.org/format_3594.description: Photo CD format, which is the highest resolution format for images on a CD.|PCD was developed by Kodak. A PCD file contains five different resolution (ranging from low to high) of a slide or film negative. Due to it PCD is often used by many photographers and graphics professionals for high-end printed applications.

http://edamontology.org/format_3593.label: im
http://edamontology.org/format_3593.description: IM is a format used by LabEye and other applications based on the IFUNC image processing library.|IFUNC library reads and writes most uncompressed interchange versions of this format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3592.label: bmp
http://edamontology.org/format_3592.description: Standard bitmap storage format in the Microsoft Windows environment.|Although it is based on Windows internal bitmap data structures, it is supported by many non-Windows and non-PC applications.

http://edamontology.org/format_3591.label: tiff
http://edamontology.org/format_3591.description: A versatile bitmap format.|The TIFF format is perhaps the most versatile and diverse bitmap format in existence. Its extensible nature and support for numerous data compression schemes allow developers to customize the TIFF format to fit any peculiar data storage needs.

http://edamontology.org/format_3590.label: hdf5
http://edamontology.org/format_3590.description: HDF5 is a generic hierarchical data file format used to store and organize large amounts of data.|An HDF5 file appears to the user as a directed graph. The nodes of this graph are the higher-level HDF5 objects that are exposed by the HDF5 APIs: Groups, Datasets, Named datatypes.

http://edamontology.org/format_3579.label: JPG
http://edamontology.org/format_3579.description: Joint Picture Group file format for lossy graphics file.|Sequence of segments with markers. Begins with byte of 0xFF and follows by marker type.

http://edamontology.org/format_3578.label: IDAT
http://edamontology.org/format_3578.description: Proprietary file format for (raw) BeadArray data used by genomewide profiling platforms from Illumina Inc. This format is output directly from the scanner and stores summary intensities for each probe-type on an array.

http://edamontology.org/format_3549.label: nii
http://edamontology.org/format_3549.description: Medical image and metadata format of the Neuroimaging Informatics Technology Initiative.

http://edamontology.org/format_3548.label: DICOM format
http://edamontology.org/format_3548.description: Medical image format corresponding to the Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine (DICOM) standard.

http://edamontology.org/format_3326.label: Data index format
http://edamontology.org/format_3326.description: Format of a data index of some type.

http://edamontology.org/format_3700.label: Tabix index file format
http://edamontology.org/format_3700.description: Index file format used by the samtools package to index TAB-delimited genome position files.

http://edamontology.org/format_3624.label: snpeffdb
http://edamontology.org/format_3624.description: An index of a genome database, indexed for use by the snpeff tool.

http://edamontology.org/format_3491.label: ebwtl
http://edamontology.org/format_3491.description: Bowtie format for indexed reference genome for "large" genomes.

http://edamontology.org/format_3484.label: ebwt
http://edamontology.org/format_3484.description: Bowtie format for indexed reference genome for "small" genomes.

http://edamontology.org/format_3284.label: SFF
http://edamontology.org/format_3284.description: Standard flowgram format (SFF) is a binary file format used to encode results of pyrosequencing from the 454 Life Sciences platform for high-throughput sequencing.

http://edamontology.org/format_3020.label: BCF
http://edamontology.org/format_3020.description: BCF, the binary version of Variant Call Format (VCF) for sequence variation (indels, polymorphisms, structural variation).

http://edamontology.org/format_3018.label: ZTR
http://edamontology.org/format_3018.description: ZTR format for storing chromatogram data from DNA sequencing instruments.

http://edamontology.org/format_3017.label: SRF
http://edamontology.org/format_3017.description: Sequence Read Format (SRF) of sequence trace data. Supports submission to the NCBI Short Read Archive.

http://edamontology.org/format_3010.label: .nib
http://edamontology.org/format_3010.description: .nib (nibble) binary format of a nucleotide sequence using 4 bits per nucleotide (including unknown) and its lower-case 'masking'.

http://edamontology.org/format_3009.label: 2bit
http://edamontology.org/format_3009.description: 2bit binary format of nucleotide sequences using 2 bits per nucleotide. In addition encodes unknown nucleotides and lower-case 'masking'.

http://edamontology.org/format_3006.label: bigWig
http://edamontology.org/format_3006.description: bigWig format for large sequence annotation tracks that consist of a value for each sequence position. Similar to textual WIG format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3004.label: bigBed
http://edamontology.org/format_3004.description: bigBed format for large sequence annotation tracks, similar to textual BED format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3000.label: AB1
http://edamontology.org/format_3000.description: AB1 binary format of raw DNA sequence reads (output of Applied Biosystems' sequencing analysis software). Contains an electropherogram and the DNA base sequence.|AB1 uses the generic binary Applied Biosystems, Inc. Format (ABIF).

http://edamontology.org/format_2572.label: BAM
http://edamontology.org/format_2572.description: BAM format, the binary, BGZF-formatted compressed version of SAM format for alignment of nucleotide sequences (e.g. sequencing reads) to (a) reference sequence(s). May contain base-call and alignment qualities and other data.

http://edamontology.org/format_1632.label: SCF
http://edamontology.org/format_1632.description: Staden Chromatogram Files format (SCF) of base-called sequence reads, qualities, and other metadata.

http://edamontology.org/format_1628.label: ABI
http://edamontology.org/format_1628.description: A format of raw sequence read data from an Applied Biosystems sequencing machine.

http://edamontology.org/format_2332.label: XML
http://edamontology.org/format_2332.description: eXtensible Markup Language (XML) format.|Data in XML format can be serialised into text, or binary format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3836.label: BLAST XML v2 results format
http://edamontology.org/format_3836.description: XML format as produced by the NCBI Blast package v2.

http://edamontology.org/format_3835.label: TIDE TXT
http://edamontology.org/format_3835.description: Format supported by the Tide tool for identifying peptides from tandem mass spectra.

http://edamontology.org/format_3834.label: mzData
http://edamontology.org/format_3834.description: Now deprecated data format of the HUPO Proteomics Standards Initiative.  Replaced by mzML (format_3244).

http://edamontology.org/format_3833.label: featureXML
http://edamontology.org/format_3833.description: OpenMS format for quantitation results (LC/MS features).

http://edamontology.org/format_3832.label: consensusXML
http://edamontology.org/format_3832.description: OpenMS format for grouping features in one map or across several maps.

http://edamontology.org/format_3825.label: nmrML
http://edamontology.org/format_3825.description: nmrML is an MSI supported XML-based open access format for metabolomics NMR raw and processed spectral data. It is accompanies by an nmrCV (controlled vocabulary) to allow ontology-based annotations.

http://edamontology.org/format_3821.label: VisML
http://edamontology.org/format_3821.description: Default XML format of VisANT, containing all the network information.

http://edamontology.org/format_3782.label: BioC
http://edamontology.org/format_3782.description: BioC is a standardised XML format for sharing and integrating text data and annotations.

http://edamontology.org/format_3770.label: UniProtKB XML
http://edamontology.org/format_3770.description: UniProtKB XML sequence features format is an XML format available for downloading UniProt entries.

http://edamontology.org/format_3764.label: idXML
http://edamontology.org/format_3764.description: XML file format for files containing information about peptide identifications from mass spectrometry data analysis carried out with OpenMS.

http://edamontology.org/format_3747.label: protXML
http://edamontology.org/format_3747.description: A format for storage, exchange, and processing of protein identifications created from ms/ms-derived peptide sequence data.|No human-consumable information about this format is available (see http://tools.proteomecenter.org/wiki/index.php?title=Formats:protXML).

http://edamontology.org/format_3726.label: PMML
http://edamontology.org/format_3726.description: PMML uses XML to represent mining models. The structure of the models is described by an XML Schema.| One or more mining models can be contained in a PMML document.

http://edamontology.org/format_3725.label: SBOL
http://edamontology.org/format_3725.description: Synthetic Biology Open Language (SBOL) is an XML format for the specification and exchange of biological design information in synthetic biology.|SBOL introduces a standardised format for the electronic exchange of information on the structural and functional aspects of biological designs.

http://edamontology.org/format_3711.label: X!Tandem XML
http://edamontology.org/format_3711.description: Output format used by X! series search engines that is based on the XML language BIOML.

http://edamontology.org/format_3692.label: SBGN-ML
http://edamontology.org/format_3692.description: SBGN-ML is an XML format for Systems Biology Graphical Notation (SBGN) diagrams of biological pathways or networks.

http://edamontology.org/format_3690.label: BDML
http://edamontology.org/format_3690.description: Biological Dynamics Markup Language (BDML) is an XML format for quantitative data describing biological dynamics.

http://edamontology.org/format_3689.label: BCML
http://edamontology.org/format_3689.description: Biological Connection Markup Language (BCML) is an XML format for biological pathways.

http://edamontology.org/format_3685.label: SED-ML
http://edamontology.org/format_3685.description: Simulation Experiment Description Markup Language (SED-ML) is an XML format for encoding simulation setups, according to the MIASE (Minimum Information About a Simulation Experiment) requirements.

http://edamontology.org/format_3684.label: PRIDE XML
http://edamontology.org/format_3684.description: PRIDE XML is an XML format for mass spectra, peptide and protein identifications, and metadata about a corresponding measurement, sample, experiment.

http://edamontology.org/format_3683.label: qcML
http://edamontology.org/format_3683.description: qcML is an XML format for quality-related data of mass spectrometry and other high-throughput measurements.|The focus of qcML is towards mass spectrometry based proteomics, but the format is suitable for metabolomics and sequencing as well.

http://edamontology.org/format_3682.label: imzML metadata file
http://edamontology.org/format_3682.description: imzML metadata is a data format for mass spectrometry imaging metadata.|imzML data are recorded in 2 files: '.imzXML' is a metadata XML file based on mzML by HUPO-PSI, and '.ibd' is a binary file containing the mass spectra. This entry is for the metadata XML file

http://edamontology.org/format_3657.label: GPML
http://edamontology.org/format_3657.description: Graphical Pathway Markup Language (GPML) is an XML format used for exchanging biological pathways.

http://edamontology.org/format_3655.label: pepXML
http://edamontology.org/format_3655.description: Open data format for the storage, exchange, and processing of peptide sequence assignments of MS/MS scans, intended to provide a common data output format for many different MS/MS search engines and subsequent peptide-level analyses.

http://edamontology.org/format_3604.label: SVG
http://edamontology.org/format_3604.description: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) is an XML-based vector image format for two-dimensional graphics with support for interactivity and animation.| The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.

http://edamontology.org/format_3331.label: BLAST XML results format
http://edamontology.org/format_3331.description: XML format as produced by the NCBI Blast package

http://edamontology.org/format_3261.label: RDF/XML
http://edamontology.org/format_3261.description: Resource Description Framework (RDF) XML format.|RDF/XML is a serialisation syntax for OWL DL, but not for OWL Full.

http://edamontology.org/format_3250.label: spML
http://edamontology.org/format_3250.description: spML is the format for describing proteomics sample processing, other than using gels, prior to mass spectrometric protein identification, standardised by HUPO PSI PS. It may also be applicable for metabolomics.

http://edamontology.org/format_3249.label: GelML
http://edamontology.org/format_3249.description: GelML is the format for describing the process of gel electrophoresis, standardised by HUPO PSI PS.

http://edamontology.org/format_3248.label: mzQuantML
http://edamontology.org/format_3248.description: mzQuantML is the format for quantitation values associated with peptides, proteins and small molecules from mass spectra, standardised by HUPO PSI PI. It can be used for outputs of quantitation software for proteomics.

http://edamontology.org/format_3247.label: mzIdentML
http://edamontology.org/format_3247.description: mzIdentML is the exchange format for peptides and proteins identified from mass spectra, standardised by HUPO PSI PI. It can be used for outputs of proteomics search engines.

http://edamontology.org/format_3246.label: TraML
http://edamontology.org/format_3246.description: TraML (Transition Markup Language) is the format for mass spectrometry transitions, standardised by HUPO PSI MSS.

http://edamontology.org/format_3244.label: mzML
http://edamontology.org/format_3244.description: mzML format for raw spectrometer output data, standardised by HUPO PSI MSS.|mzML is the successor and unifier of the mzData format developed by PSI and mzXML developed at the Seattle Proteome Center.

http://edamontology.org/format_3240.label: CellML
http://edamontology.org/format_3240.description: CellML, the format for mathematical models of biological and other networks.

http://edamontology.org/format_3239.label: CopasiML
http://edamontology.org/format_3239.description: CopasiML, the native format of COPASI.

http://edamontology.org/format_3163.label: GCDML
http://edamontology.org/format_3163.description: GCDML XML format for genome and metagenome metadata according to MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS information standards, standardised by the Genomic Standards Consortium (GSC).

http://edamontology.org/format_3161.label: MAGE-ML
http://edamontology.org/format_3161.description: MAGE-ML XML format for microarray expression data, standardised by MGED (now FGED).

http://edamontology.org/format_3160.label: NeXML
http://edamontology.org/format_3160.description: NeXML is a standardised XML format for rich phyloinformatic data.

http://edamontology.org/format_3159.label: phyloXML
http://edamontology.org/format_3159.description: phyloXML is a standardised XML format for phylogenetic trees, networks, and associated data.

http://edamontology.org/format_3158.label: PSI MI XML (MIF)
http://edamontology.org/format_3158.description: XML Molecular Interaction Format (MIF), standardised by HUPO PSI MI.

http://edamontology.org/format_3243.label: PSI-PAR
http://edamontology.org/format_3243.description: Protein affinity format (PSI-PAR), standardised by HUPO PSI MI. It is compatible with PSI MI XML (MIF) and uses the same XML Schema.

http://edamontology.org/format_3157.label: EBI Application Result XML
http://edamontology.org/format_3157.description: EBI Application Result XML is a format returned by sequence similarity search Web services at EBI.

http://edamontology.org/format_3155.label: SBRML
http://edamontology.org/format_3155.description: Systems Biology Result Markup Language (SBRML), the standard XML format for simulated or calculated results (e.g. trajectories) of systems biology models.

http://edamontology.org/format_2585.label: SBML
http://edamontology.org/format_2585.description: Systems Biology Markup Language (SBML), the standard XML format for models of biological processes such as for example metabolism, cell signaling, and gene regulation.

http://edamontology.org/format_2558.label: EMBL-like (XML)
http://edamontology.org/format_2558.description: An XML format resembling EMBL entry format.|This concept may be used for the any non-standard EMBL-like XML formats.

http://edamontology.org/format_2204.label: EMBL format (XML)
http://edamontology.org/format_2204.description: An XML format for EMBL entries.|This is a placeholder for other more specific concepts. It should not normally be used for annotation.

http://edamontology.org/format_2352.label: BioXSD (XML)
http://edamontology.org/format_2352.description: BioXSD-schema-based XML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, Web services, and object-oriented programming.

http://edamontology.org/format_2304.label: STRING entry format (XML)
http://edamontology.org/format_2304.description: Entry format (XML) for the STRING database of protein interaction.

http://edamontology.org/format_1968.label: dasdna
http://edamontology.org/format_1968.description: DAS sequence (XML) format (nucleotide-only).|The use of this format is deprecated.

http://edamontology.org/format_1741.label: OSCAR format
http://edamontology.org/format_1741.description: OSCAR format of annotated chemical text.|OSCAR (Open-Source Chemistry Analysis Routines) software performs chemistry-specific parsing of chemical documents. It attempts to identify chemical names, ontology concepts, and chemical data from a document.

http://edamontology.org/format_1740.label: iHOP format
http://edamontology.org/format_1740.description: The format of iHOP (Information Hyperlinked over Proteins) text-mining result.

http://edamontology.org/format_1478.label: PDBML
http://edamontology.org/format_1478.description: Entry format of PDB database in PDBML (XML) format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3556.label: MHTML
http://edamontology.org/format_3556.description: MIME  HTML format for Web pages, which can include external resources, including images, Flash animations and so on.

http://edamontology.org/format_2532.label: GenBank-HTML
http://edamontology.org/format_2532.description: Genbank entry format wrapped in HTML elements.

http://edamontology.org/format_2311.label: EMBL-HTML
http://edamontology.org/format_2311.description: EMBL entry format wrapped in HTML elements.

http://edamontology.org/format_2310.label: FASTA-HTML
http://edamontology.org/format_2310.description: FASTA format wrapped in HTML elements.

http://edamontology.org/format_1740.label: iHOP format
http://edamontology.org/format_1740.description: The format of iHOP (Information Hyperlinked over Proteins) text-mining result.

http://edamontology.org/format_2330.label: Textual format
http://edamontology.org/format_2330.description: Textual format.|Data in text format can be compressed into binary format, or can be a value of an XML element or attribute. Markup formats are not considered textual (or more precisely, not plain-textual).

http://edamontology.org/format_3829.label: GPR
http://edamontology.org/format_3829.description: GenePix Results (GPR) text file format developed by Axon Instruments that is used to save GenePix Results data.

http://edamontology.org/format_3827.label: proBED
http://edamontology.org/format_3827.description: . proBED is an adaptation of BED (format_3003), which was extended to meet specific requirements entailed by proteomics data.

http://edamontology.org/format_3823.label: FASTG
http://edamontology.org/format_3823.description: FASTG is a format for faithfully representing genome assemblies in the face of allelic polymorphism and assembly uncertainty.|It is called FASTG, like FASTA, but the G stands for graph.

http://edamontology.org/format_3822.label: GML
http://edamontology.org/format_3822.description: GML (Graph Modeling Language) is a text file format supporting network data with a very easy syntax. It is used by Graphlet, Pajek, yEd, LEDA and NetworkX.

http://edamontology.org/format_3818.label: ELAND format
http://edamontology.org/format_3818.description: Tab-delimited text file format used by Eland - the read-mapping program distributed by Illumina with its sequencing analysis pipeline - which maps short Solexa sequence reads to the human reference genome.

http://edamontology.org/format_3817.label: latex
http://edamontology.org/format_3817.description: format for the LaTeX document preparation system|uses the TeX typesetting program format

http://edamontology.org/format_3816.label: Mol2
http://edamontology.org/format_3816.description: Complete, portable representation of a SYBYL molecule. ASCII file which contains all the information needed to reconstruct a SYBYL molecule.

http://edamontology.org/format_3815.label: Molfile
http://edamontology.org/format_3815.description: An MDL Molfile is a file format for holding information about the atoms, bonds, connectivity and coordinates of a molecule.

http://edamontology.org/format_3814.label: SDF
http://edamontology.org/format_3814.description: SDF is one of a family of chemical-data file formats developed by MDL Information Systems; it is intended especially for structural information.

http://edamontology.org/format_3813.label: SAMPLE file format
http://edamontology.org/format_3813.description: The SAMPLE file format contains information about each individual i.e. individual IDs, covariates, phenotypes and missing data proportions, from a GWAS study.

http://edamontology.org/format_3812.label: GEN
http://edamontology.org/format_3812.description: The GEN file format contains genetic data and describes SNPs.

synonyms: SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language
http://edamontology.org/format_3790.label: SPARQL
http://edamontology.org/format_3790.description: SPARQL (SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language) is a semantic query language for querying and manipulating data stored in Resource Description Framework (RDF) format.

http://edamontology.org/format_3789.label: XQuery
http://edamontology.org/format_3789.description: XQuery (XML Query) is a query language (format of queries) for querying and manipulating structured and unstructured data, usually in the form of XML, text, and with vendor-specific extensions for other data formats (JSON, binary, etc.).

http://edamontology.org/format_3788.label: SQL
http://edamontology.org/format_3788.description: SQL (Structured Query Language) is the de-facto standard query language (format of queries) for querying and manipulating data in relational databases.

http://edamontology.org/format_3785.label: BioNLP Shared Task format
http://edamontology.org/format_3785.description: A family of similar formats of text annotation, used by BRAT and other tools, known as BioNLP Shared Task format (BioNLP 2009 Shared Task on Event Extraction, BioNLP Shared Task 2011, BioNLP Shared Task 2013), BRAT format, BRAT standoff format, and similar.

http://edamontology.org/format_3783.label: PubTator format
http://edamontology.org/format_3783.description: Native textual export format of annotated scientific text from PubTator.

http://edamontology.org/format_3777.label: MCPD
http://edamontology.org/format_3777.description: The FAO/Bioversity/IPGRI Multi-Crop Passport Descriptors (MCPD) is an international standard format for exchange of germplasm information.

http://edamontology.org/format_3775.label: GSuite
http://edamontology.org/format_3775.description: GSuite is a tabular format for collections of genome or sequence feature tracks, suitable for integrative multi-track analysis. GSuite contains links to genome/sequence tracks, with additional metadata.

http://edamontology.org/format_3758.label: SEQUEST .out file
http://edamontology.org/format_3758.description: "Raw" result file from SEQUEST database search.

http://edamontology.org/format_3751.label: DSV
http://edamontology.org/format_3751.description: Tabular data represented as values in a text file delimited by some character.

http://edamontology.org/format_3752.label: CSV
http://edamontology.org/format_3752.description: Tabular data represented as comma-separated values in a text file.

http://edamontology.org/format_3746.description: The BIological Observation Matrix (BIOM) is a format for representing biological sample by observation contingency tables in broad areas of comparative omics. http://edamontology.org/format_3728.label: LocARNA PP
http://edamontology.org/format_3728.description: The LocARNA PP format combines sequence or alignment information and (respectively, single or consensus) ensemble probabilities into an PP 2.0 record.|Format for multiple aligned or single sequences together with the probabilistic description of the (consensus) RNA secondary structure ensemble by probabilities of base pairs, base pair stackings, and base pairs and unpaired bases in the loop of base pairs.

http://edamontology.org/format_3714.label: MaxQuant APL peaklist format
http://edamontology.org/format_3714.description: Format of peak list files from Andromeda search engine (MaxQuant) that consist of arbitrarily many spectra.

http://edamontology.org/format_3713.description: "Raw" result file from Mascot database search.

http://edamontology.org/format_3709.label: GCT/Res format
http://edamontology.org/format_3709.description: Tab-delimited text files of GenePattern that contain a column for each sample, a row for each gene, and an expression value for each gene in each sample.

http://edamontology.org/format_3693.label: AGP
http://edamontology.org/format_3693.description: AGP is a tabular format for a sequence assembly (a contig, a scaffold/supercontig, or a chromosome).

http://edamontology.org/format_3691.label: BEL
http://edamontology.org/format_3691.description: Biological Expression Language (BEL) is a textual format for representing scientific findings in life sciences in a computable form.

http://edamontology.org/format_3688.label: SBtab
http://edamontology.org/format_3688.description: SBtab is a tabular format for biochemical network models.

http://edamontology.org/format_3687.label: ISA-TAB
http://edamontology.org/format_3687.description:
The Investigation / Study / Assay (ISA) tab-delimited (TAB) format incorporates metadata from

http://edamontology.org/format_3681.label: mzTab
http://edamontology.org/format_3681.description: mzTab is a tab-delimited format for mass spectrometry-based proteomics and metabolomics results.

http://edamontology.org/format_3606.description: Textual report format for sequence quality for reports from sequencing machines.

http://edamontology.org/format_3588.label: customtrack

http://edamontology.org/format_3583.label: bedgraph
http://edamontology.org/format_3583.description: The bedGraph format allows display of continuous-valued data in track format. This display type is useful for probability scores and transcriptome data|Holds a tab-delimited chromosome /start /end / datavalue dataset.

http://edamontology.org/format_3582.label: afg

http://edamontology.org/format_3499.description: Ensembl standard format for variation data.

http://edamontology.org/format_3486.description: Some format based on the GCG format.

http://edamontology.org/format_1947.description: GCG MSF (multiple sequence file) file format.

http://edamontology.org/format_1935.label: GCG

http://edamontology.org/format_3477.description: Format of the cytoscape input file of gene expression ratios or values are specified over one or more experiments.

http://edamontology.org/format_3312.description: Format for the Genetic Data Environment (GDE).

http://edamontology.org/format_3288.description: The PED/MAP file describes data used by the Plink package.

http://edamontology.org/format_3286.label: PED
http://edamontology.org/format_3286.description: The PED file describes individuals and genetic data and is used by the Plink package.

http://edamontology.org/format_3285.description: The MAP file describes SNPs and is used by the Plink package.

http://edamontology.org/format_1200.description: SMILES ARbitrary Target Specification (SMARTS) format for chemical structure specification, which is a subset of the SMILES line notation.

http://edamontology.org/data_0006.label: Data
http://edamontology.org/data_0006.description: Information, represented in an information artefact (data record) that is 'understandable' by dedicated computational tools that can use the data as input or produce it as output.

http://edamontology.org/data_3786.label: Query script
http://edamontology.org/data_3786.description: A structured query, in form of a script, that defines a database search task.

http://edamontology.org/data_3736.label: Ecological data
