http://edamontology.org/data_0867.description: An informative report of molecular sequence alignment-derived data or metadata.|Use this for any computer-generated reports on sequence alignments, and for general information (metadata) on a sequence alignment, such as a description, sequence identifiers and alignment score.

http://edamontology.org/data_3181.label: Sequence assembly report
http://edamontology.org/data_3181.description: An informative report about a DNA sequence assembly.|This might include an overall quality assement of the assembly and summary statistics including counts, average length and number of bases for reads, matches and non-matches, contigs, reads in pairs etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_2161.label: Sequence similarity plot
http://edamontology.org/data_2161.description: A plot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.|Use this concept for calculated substitution rates, relative site variability, data on sites with biased properties, highly conserved or very poorly conserved sites, regions, blocks etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_0862.label: Dotplot
http://edamontology.org/data_0862.description: A dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.

http://edamontology.org/data_2044.label: Sequence
http://edamontology.org/data_2044.description: One or more molecular sequences, possibly with associated annotation.|This concept is a placeholder of concepts for primary sequence data including raw sequences and sequence records.  It should not normally be used for derivatives such as sequence alignments, motifs or profiles.

http://edamontology.org/data_2977.label: Nucleic acid sequence
http://edamontology.org/data_2977.description: One or more nucleic acid sequences, possibly with associated annotation.

http://edamontology.org/data_2887.label: Nucleic acid sequence record
http://edamontology.org/data_2887.description: A nucleic acid sequence and associated metadata.

http://edamontology.org/data_2976.label: Protein sequence
http://edamontology.org/data_2976.description: One or more protein sequences, possibly with associated annotation.

http://edamontology.org/data_2974.label: Protein sequence (raw)
http://edamontology.org/data_2974.description: A raw protein sequence (string of characters).

http://edamontology.org/data_2886.label: Protein sequence record
http://edamontology.org/data_2886.description: A protein sequence and associated metadata.

http://edamontology.org/data_0849.label: Sequence record
http://edamontology.org/data_0849.description: A molecular sequence and associated metadata.

http://edamontology.org/data_2887.label: Nucleic acid sequence record
http://edamontology.org/data_2887.description: A nucleic acid sequence and associated metadata.

http://edamontology.org/data_2886.label: Protein sequence record
http://edamontology.org/data_2886.description: A protein sequence and associated metadata.

http://edamontology.org/data_0848.label: Raw sequence
http://edamontology.org/data_0848.description: A raw molecular sequence (string of characters) which might include ambiguity, unknown positions and non-sequence characters.|Non-sequence characters may be used for example for gaps and translation stop.

http://edamontology.org/data_2974.label: Protein sequence (raw)
http://edamontology.org/data_2974.description: A raw protein sequence (string of characters).

http://edamontology.org/data_2042.label: Evidence
http://edamontology.org/data_2042.description: Typically a statement about some data or results, including evidence or the source of a statement, which may include computational prediction, laboratory experiment, literature reference etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_2019.label: Map data
http://edamontology.org/data_2019.description: A molecular map (genetic or physical), an attribute of such a map, or data extracted from or derived from the analysis of such a map.|This is a broad data type and is used a placeholder for other, more specific types.  It is primarily intended to help navigation of EDAM and would not typically be used for annotation. It includes concepts that are best described as scientific text or closely concerned with or derived from text.

http://edamontology.org/data_2012.label: Sequence coordinates
http://edamontology.org/data_2012.description: A position in a map (for example a genetic map), either a single position (point) or a region / interval.|This includes positions in genomes based on a reference sequence. A position may be specified for any mappable object, i.e. anything that may have positional information such as a physical position in a chromosome. Data might include sequence region name, strand, coordinate system name, assembly name, start position and end position.

http://edamontology.org/data_3236.label: Cytoband position
http://edamontology.org/data_3236.description: The position of a cytogenetic band in a genome.|Information might include start and end position in a chromosome sequence, chromosome identifier, name of band and so on.

http://edamontology.org/data_1864.label: Map set data
http://edamontology.org/data_1864.description: Data describing a set of multiple genetic or physical maps, typically sharing a common set of features which are mapped.

http://edamontology.org/data_1274.label: Map
http://edamontology.org/data_1274.description: A map of (typically one) DNA sequence annotated with positional or non-positional features.

http://edamontology.org/data_1280.label: Physical map
http://edamontology.org/data_1280.description: A map of DNA (linear or circular) annotated with physical features or landmarks such as restriction sites, cloned DNA fragments, genes or genetic markers, along with the physical distances between them.|Distance in a physical map is measured in base pairs. A physical map might be ordered relative to a reference map (typically a genetic map) in the process of genome sequencing.

http://edamontology.org/data_2870.label: Radiation hybrid map
http://edamontology.org/data_2870.description: A map showing distance between genetic markers estimated by radiation-induced breaks in a chromosome.|The radiation method can break very closely linked markers providing a more detailed map.  Most genetic markers and subsequences may be located to a defined map position and with a more precise estimates of distance than a linkage map.

http://edamontology.org/data_1283.label: Cytogenetic map
http://edamontology.org/data_1283.description: A map showing banding patterns derived from direct observation of a stained chromosome.|This is the lowest-resolution physical map and can provide only rough estimates of physical (base pair) distances.  Like a genetic map, they are limited to genetic markers of traits observable only in whole organisms.

http://edamontology.org/data_1859.label: Deletion map
http://edamontology.org/data_1859.description: A cytogenetic map showing chromosome banding patterns in mutant cell lines relative to the wild type.|A cytogenetic map is built from a set of mutant cell lines with sub-chromosomal deletions and a reference wild-type line ('genome deletion panel'). The panel is used to map markers onto the genome by comparing mutant to wild-type banding patterns. Markers are linked (occur in the same deleted region) if they share the same banding pattern (presence or absence) as the deletion panel.

http://edamontology.org/data_1279.label: Sequence map
http://edamontology.org/data_1279.description: A map of genetic markers in a contiguous, assembled genomic sequence, with the sizes and separation of markers measured in base pairs.|A sequence map typically includes annotation on significant subsequences such as contigs, haplotypes and genes. The contigs shown will (typically) be a set of small overlapping clones representing a complete chromosomal segment.

http://edamontology.org/data_1289.label: Restriction map
http://edamontology.org/data_1289.description: Image of the restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in a nucleic acid sequence.

http://edamontology.org/data_1288.label: Genome map
http://edamontology.org/data_1288.description: Sequence map of a whole genome.

http://edamontology.org/data_1286.label: Plasmid map
http://edamontology.org/data_1286.description: Sequence map of a plasmid (circular DNA).

http://edamontology.org/data_1285.label: Gene map
http://edamontology.org/data_1285.description: Sequence map of a single gene annotated with genetic features such as introns, exons, untranslated regions, polyA signals, promoters, enhancers and (possibly) mutations defining alleles of a gene.

http://edamontology.org/data_1278.label: Genetic map
http://edamontology.org/data_1278.description: A map showing the relative positions of genetic markers in a nucleic acid sequence, based on estimation of non-physical distance such as recombination frequencies.|A genetic (linkage) map indicates the proximity of two genes on a chromosome, whether two genes are linked and the frequency they are transmitted together to an offspring. They are limited to genetic markers of traits observable only in whole organisms.

http://edamontology.org/data_1863.label: Haplotype map
http://edamontology.org/data_1863.description: A map of haplotypes in a genome or other sequence, describing common patterns of genetic variation.

http://edamontology.org/data_1860.label: QTL map
http://edamontology.org/data_1860.description: A genetic map which shows the approximate location of quantitative trait loci (QTL) between two or more markers.

http://edamontology.org/data_1284.label: DNA transduction map
http://edamontology.org/data_1284.description: A gene map showing distances between loci based on relative cotransduction frequencies.

http://edamontology.org/data_1916.label: Alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_1916.description: An alignment of molecular sequences, structures or profiles derived from them.

http://edamontology.org/data_3154.label: Protein alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_3154.description: An alignment of protein sequences and/or structures.

http://edamontology.org/data_0878.label: Secondary structure alignment (protein)
http://edamontology.org/data_0878.description: Alignment of the (1D representations of) secondary structure of two or more proteins.

http://edamontology.org/data_2366.label: Secondary structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_2366.description: Alignment of the (1D representations of) secondary structure of two or more molecules.

http://edamontology.org/data_0881.label: Secondary structure alignment (RNA)
http://edamontology.org/data_0881.description: Alignment of the (1D representations of) secondary structure of two or more RNA molecules.

http://edamontology.org/data_0878.label: Secondary structure alignment (protein)
http://edamontology.org/data_0878.description: Alignment of the (1D representations of) secondary structure of two or more proteins.

http://edamontology.org/data_0893.label: Sequence-structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_0893.description: An alignment of molecular sequence to structure (from threading sequence(s) through 3D structure or representation of structure(s)).

http://edamontology.org/data_0890.label: Structural (3D) profile alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_0890.description: A 3D profile-3D profile alignment (each profile representing structures or a structure alignment).

http://edamontology.org/data_0886.label: Structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_0886.description: Alignment (superimposition) of molecular tertiary (3D) structures.|A tertiary structure alignment will include the untransformed coordinates of one macromolecule, followed by the second (or subsequent) structure(s) with all the coordinates transformed (by rotation / translation) to give a superposition.

http://edamontology.org/data_1482.label: Structure alignment (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/data_1482.description: Alignment (superimposition) of nucleic acid tertiary (3D) structures.

http://edamontology.org/data_1479.label: Structure alignment (pair)
http://edamontology.org/data_1479.description: Alignment (superimposition) of exactly two molecular tertiary (3D) structures.

http://edamontology.org/data_0869.label: Sequence-profile alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_0869.description: Alignment of one or more molecular sequence(s) to one or more sequence profile(s) (each profile typically representing a sequence alignment).|Data associated with the alignment might also be included, e.g. ranked list of best-scoring sequences and a graphical representation of scores.

http://edamontology.org/data_0868.label: Profile-profile alignment
http://edamontology.org/data_0868.description: A profile-profile alignment (each profile typically representing a sequence alignment).

http://edamontology.org/data_1385.label: Sequence alignment (hybrid)
http://edamontology.org/data_1385.description: Alignment of multiple molecular sequences of different types.|Hybrid sequence alignments include for example genomic DNA to EST, cDNA or mRNA.

http://edamontology.org/data_1381.label: Sequence alignment (pair)
http://edamontology.org/data_1381.description: Alignment of exactly two molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1772.label: Score
http://edamontology.org/data_1772.description: A numerical value, that is some type of scored value arising for example from a prediction method.

http://edamontology.org/data_3756.label: Localisation score
http://edamontology.org/data_3756.description: Score for localization of one or more post-translational modifications in peptide sequence measured by mass spectrometry.

http://edamontology.org/data_1394.label: Alignment score or penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1394.description: A simple floating point number defining the penalty for opening or extending a gap in an alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_2137.label: Gap penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_2137.description: A penalty for introducing or extending a gap in an alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_1399.label: Gap separation penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1399.description: A penalty for gaps that are close together in an alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_1398.label: Gap extension penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1398.description: A penalty for extending a gap in an alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_1411.label: Terminal gap extension penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1411.description: A number defining the penalty for extending gaps at the termini of an alignment, either from the N/C terminal of protein or 5'/3' terminal of nucleotide sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1397.label: Gap opening penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1397.description: A penalty for opening a gap in an alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_1410.label: Terminal gap opening penalty
http://edamontology.org/data_1410.description: A number defining the penalty for opening gaps at the termini of an alignment, either from the N/C terminal of protein or 5'/3' terminal of nucleotide sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1403.label: Drop off score
http://edamontology.org/data_1403.description: This is the threshold drop in score at which extension of word alignment is halted.

http://edamontology.org/data_1402.label: Mismatch penalty score
http://edamontology.org/data_1402.description: The score (penalty) for a 'mismatch' used in various alignment and sequence database search applications with simple scoring schemes.

http://edamontology.org/data_1401.label: Match reward score
http://edamontology.org/data_1401.description: The score for a 'match' used in various sequence database search applications with simple scoring schemes.

http://edamontology.org/data_0951.label: Statistical estimate score
http://edamontology.org/data_0951.description: A value representing estimated statistical significance of some observed data; typically sequence database hits.

http://edamontology.org/data_1669.label: P-value
http://edamontology.org/data_1669.description: The P-value is the probability of obtaining by random chance a result that is at least as extreme as an observed result, assuming a NULL hypothesis is true.|A z-value might be specified as a threshold for reporting hits from database searches.

http://edamontology.org/data_1668.label: Z-value
http://edamontology.org/data_1668.description: The z-value is the number of standard deviations a data value is above or below a mean value.|A z-value might be specified as a threshold for reporting hits from database searches.

http://edamontology.org/data_1667.label: E-value
http://edamontology.org/data_1667.description: A simple floating point number defining the lower or upper limit of an expectation value (E-value).|An expectation value (E-Value) is the expected number of observations which are at least as extreme as observations expected to occur by random chance. The E-value describes the number of hits with a given score or better that are expected to occur at random when searching a database of a particular size. It decreases exponentially with the score (S) of a hit. A low E value indicates a more significant score.

http://edamontology.org/data_0888.label: Structure similarity score
http://edamontology.org/data_0888.description: A value representing molecular structure similarity, measured from structure alignment or some other type of structure comparison.

http://edamontology.org/data_1498.label: Tanimoto similarity score
http://edamontology.org/data_1498.description: A measure of the similarity between two ligand fingerprints.|A ligand fingerprint is derived from ligand structural data from a Protein DataBank file. It reflects the elements or groups present or absent, covalent bonds and bond orders and the bonded environment in terms of SATIS codes and BLEEP atom types.

http://edamontology.org/data_1497.label: Root-mean-square deviation
http://edamontology.org/data_1497.description: Root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) is calculated to measure the average distance between superimposed macromolecular coordinates.

http://edamontology.org/data_0865.label: Sequence similarity score
http://edamontology.org/data_0865.description: A value representing molecular sequence similarity.

http://edamontology.org/data_1413.label: Sequence similarity
http://edamontology.org/data_1413.description: Sequence similarity is the similarity (expressed as a percentage) of two molecular sequences calculated from their alignment, a scoring matrix for scoring characters substitutions and penalties for gap insertion and extension.|Data Type is float probably.

http://edamontology.org/data_2335.label: Bit score
http://edamontology.org/data_2335.description: A score derived from the alignment of two sequences, which is then normalised with respect to the scoring system.|Bit scores are normalised with respect to the scoring system and therefore can be used to compare alignment scores from different searches.

http://edamontology.org/data_1412.label: Sequence identity
http://edamontology.org/data_1412.description: Sequence identity is the number (%) of matches (identical characters) in positions from an alignment of two molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1255.label: Sequence features
http://edamontology.org/data_1255.description: Annotation of positional features of molecular sequence(s), i.e. that can be mapped to position(s) in the sequence.|This includes annotation of positional sequence features, organised into a standard feature table, or any other report of sequence features.  General feature reports are a source of sequence feature table information although internal conversion would be required.

http://edamontology.org/data_3002.label: Annotation track
http://edamontology.org/data_3002.description: Annotation of one particular positional feature on a biomolecular (typically genome) sequence, suitable for import and display in a genome browser.

http://edamontology.org/data_1277.label: Protein features
http://edamontology.org/data_1277.description: An informative report on intrinsic positional features of a protein sequence.|This includes protein sequence feature annotation in any known sequence feature table format and any other report of protein features.

http://edamontology.org/data_1276.label: Nucleic acid features
http://edamontology.org/data_1276.description: An informative report on intrinsic positional features of a nucleotide sequence.|This includes nucleotide sequence feature annotation in any known sequence feature table format and any other report of nucleic acid features.

synonyms: Nucleic acid features (gene and transcript structure)
http://edamontology.org/data_0916.label: Gene report
http://edamontology.org/data_0916.description: A report on predicted or actual gene structure, regions which make an RNA product and features such as promoters, coding regions, splice sites etc.|This includes any report on a particular locus or gene.  This might include the gene name, description, summary and so on. It can include details about the function of a gene, such as its encoded protein or a functional classification of the gene sequence along according to the encoded protein(s).

http://edamontology.org/data_3134.label: Gene transcript report
http://edamontology.org/data_3134.description: An informative report on features of a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules including precursor RNA, primary (unprocessed) transcript and fully processed molecules. This includes reports on a specific gene transcript, clone or EST.|This includes 5'untranslated region (5'UTR), coding sequences (CDS), exons, intervening sequences (intron) and 3'untranslated regions (3'UTR).

http://edamontology.org/data_1270.label: Feature table
http://edamontology.org/data_1270.description: Annotation of positional sequence features, organised into a standard feature table.

http://edamontology.org/data_0968.label: Keyword
http://edamontology.org/data_0968.description: Keyword(s) or phrase(s) used (typically) for text-searching purposes.|Boolean operators (AND, OR and NOT) and wildcard characters may be allowed.

http://edamontology.org/data_2007.label: UniProt keyword
http://edamontology.org/data_2007.description: A word or phrase that can appear in the keywords field (KW line) of entries from the UniProt database.

http://edamontology.org/data_0955.label: Data index
http://edamontology.org/data_0955.description: An index of data of biological relevance.

http://edamontology.org/data_3210.label: Genome index
http://edamontology.org/data_3210.description: An index of a genome sequence.|Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_0950.label: Mathematical model
http://edamontology.org/data_0950.description: A biological model represented in mathematical terms.

http://edamontology.org/data_3241.label: Kinetic model
http://edamontology.org/data_3241.description: Mathematical model of a network, that contains biochemical kinetics.

http://edamontology.org/data_1439.label: DNA substitution model
http://edamontology.org/data_1439.description: A model of DNA substitution that explains a DNA sequence alignment, derived from phylogenetic tree analysis.

http://edamontology.org/data_1364.label: Hidden Markov model
http://edamontology.org/data_1364.description: A statistical Markov model of a system which is assumed to be a Markov process with unobserved (hidden) states.  For example, a hidden Markov model representation of a set or alignment of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1347.label: Dirichlet distribution
http://edamontology.org/data_1347.description: Dirichlet distribution used by hidden Markov model analysis programs.

http://edamontology.org/data_0914.label: Codon usage data
http://edamontology.org/data_0914.description: Data derived from analysis of codon usage (typically a codon usage table) of DNA sequences.|This is a broad data type and is used a placeholder for other, more specific types.

http://edamontology.org/data_2865.label: Codon usage bias
http://edamontology.org/data_2865.description: A numerical measure of differences in the frequency of occurrence of synonymous codons in DNA sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1602.label: Codon usage fraction difference
http://edamontology.org/data_1602.description: The differences in codon usage fractions between two codon usage tables.

http://edamontology.org/data_1600.label: Codon usage bias plot
http://edamontology.org/data_1600.description: A plot of the synonymous codon usage calculated for windows over a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/data_1598.label: Genetic code
http://edamontology.org/data_1598.description: A genetic code for an organism.|A genetic code need not include detailed codon usage information.

http://edamontology.org/data_1597.label: Codon usage table
http://edamontology.org/data_1597.description: Table of codon usage data calculated from one or more nucleic acid sequences.|A codon usage table might include the codon usage table name, optional comments and a table with columns for codons and corresponding codon usage data. A genetic code can be extracted from or represented by a codon usage table.

http://edamontology.org/data_0889.label: Structural profile
http://edamontology.org/data_0889.description: Some type of structural (3D) profile or template (representing a structure or structure alignment).

http://edamontology.org/data_0883.label: Structure
http://edamontology.org/data_0883.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a macromolecular tertiary (3D) structure or part of a structure.|The coordinate data may be predicted or real.

http://edamontology.org/data_3806.label: 3D EM Mask
http://edamontology.org/data_3806.description: Annotation on a structural 3D EM Map from electron microscopy. This might include one or several locations in the map of the known features of a particular macromolecule.

http://edamontology.org/data_3805.label: 3D EM Map
http://edamontology.org/data_3805.description: Structural 3D model (volume map) from electron microscopy.

http://edamontology.org/data_2850.label: Lipid structure
http://edamontology.org/data_2850.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a lipid structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_1463.label: Small molecule structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1463.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for the (3D) structure of a small molecule, such as any common chemical compound.

http://edamontology.org/data_2852.label: Toxin structure
http://edamontology.org/data_2852.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for the (3D) structure of a toxin.

http://edamontology.org/data_2851.label: Drug structure
http://edamontology.org/data_2851.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for the (3D) structure of a drug.

http://edamontology.org/data_1462.label: Carbohydrate structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1462.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a carbohydrate (3D) structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_1460.label: Protein structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1460.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a protein tertiary (3D) structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_2878.label: Protein structural motif
http://edamontology.org/data_2878.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a protein (3D) structural motif; any group of contiguous or non-contiguous amino acid residues but typically those forming a feature with a structural or functional role.

http://edamontology.org/data_2877.label: Protein complex
http://edamontology.org/data_2877.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a multi-protein complex; two or more polypeptides chains in a stable, functional association with one another.

http://edamontology.org/data_1756.label: Protein residue
http://edamontology.org/data_1756.description: Data on a single amino acid residue position in a protein structure.|This is a broad data type and is used a placeholder for other, more specific types.  It is primarily intended to help navigation of EDAM and would not typically be used for annotation.

http://edamontology.org/data_1755.label: Protein atom
http://edamontology.org/data_1755.description: Data on a single atom from a protein structure.|This is a broad data type and is used a placeholder for other, more specific types.  It is primarily intended to help navigation of EDAM and would not typically be used for annotation.

http://edamontology.org/data_1470.label: C-alpha trace
http://edamontology.org/data_1470.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a protein tertiary (3D) structure (typically C-alpha atoms only).|C-beta atoms from amino acid side-chains may be included.

http://edamontology.org/data_1468.label: Protein domain
http://edamontology.org/data_1468.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for the tertiary (3D) structure of a protein domain.

http://edamontology.org/data_1467.label: Protein chain
http://edamontology.org/data_1467.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for the tertiary (3D) structure of a polypeptide chain.

http://edamontology.org/data_1461.label: Protein-ligand complex
http://edamontology.org/data_1461.description: The structure of a protein in complex with a ligand, typically a small molecule such as an enzyme substrate or cofactor, but possibly another macromolecule.|This includes interactions of proteins with atoms, ions and small molecules or macromolecules such as nucleic acids or other polypeptides.  For stable inter-polypeptide interactions use 'Protein complex' instead.

http://edamontology.org/data_1459.label: Nucleic acid structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1459.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a nucleic acid tertiary (3D) structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_1465.label: RNA structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1465.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for an RNA tertiary (3D) structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_1466.label: tRNA structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1466.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a tRNA tertiary (3D) structure, including tmRNA, snoRNAs etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_0880.label: RNA secondary structure
http://edamontology.org/data_0880.description: An informative report of secondary structure (predicted or real) of an RNA molecule.|This includes thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures such as knots, pseudoknots etc.

http://edamontology.org/data_1464.label: DNA structure
http://edamontology.org/data_1464.description: 3D coordinate and associated data for a DNA tertiary (3D) structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_0860.label: Sequence signature data
http://edamontology.org/data_0860.description: Data concering concerning specific or conserved pattern in molecular sequences and the classifiers used for their identification, including sequence motifs, profiles or other diagnostic element.|This can include metadata about a motif or sequence profile such as its name, length, technical details about the profile construction, and so on.

http://edamontology.org/data_1354.label: Sequence profile
http://edamontology.org/data_1354.description: Some type of statistical model representing a (typically multiple) sequence alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_2854.label: Position-specific scoring matrix
http://edamontology.org/data_2854.description: A simple matrix of numbers, where each value (or column of values) is derived derived from analysis of the corresponding position in a sequence alignment.

http://edamontology.org/data_1365.label: Fingerprint
http://edamontology.org/data_1365.description: One or more fingerprints (sequence classifiers) as used in the PRINTS database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1363.label: Information content matrix
http://edamontology.org/data_1363.description: A profile (typically representing a sequence alignment) derived from a matrix of nucleotide (or amino acid) counts per position that reflects information content at each position.

http://edamontology.org/data_1362.label: Position weight matrix
http://edamontology.org/data_1362.description: A profile (typically representing a sequence alignment) that is weighted matrix of nucleotide (or amino acid) counts per position.|Contributions of individual sequences to the matrix might be uneven (weighted).

http://edamontology.org/data_1361.label: Position frequency matrix
http://edamontology.org/data_1361.description: A profile (typically representing a sequence alignment) that is a simple matrix of nucleotide (or amino acid) counts per position.

http://edamontology.org/data_1364.label: Hidden Markov model
http://edamontology.org/data_1364.description: A statistical Markov model of a system which is assumed to be a Markov process with unobserved (hidden) states.  For example, a hidden Markov model representation of a set or alignment of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1353.label: Sequence motif
http://edamontology.org/data_1353.description: Any specific or conserved pattern (typically expressed as a regular expression) in a molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/data_0858.label: Sequence signature matches
http://edamontology.org/data_0858.description: Report on the location of matches in one or more sequences to profiles, motifs (conserved or functional patterns) or other signatures.|This ncluding reports of hits from a search of a protein secondary or domain database.

http://edamontology.org/data_0850.label: Sequence set
http://edamontology.org/data_0850.description: A collection of multiple molecular sequences and associated metadata that do not (typically) correspond to molecular sequence database records or entries and which (typically) are derived from some analytical method.|This concept may be used for arbitrary sequence sets and associated data arising from processing.

http://edamontology.org/data_1235.label: Sequence cluster
http://edamontology.org/data_1235.description: A set of sequences that have been clustered or otherwise classified as belonging to a group including (typically) sequence cluster information.|The cluster might include sequences identifiers, short descriptions, alignment and summary information.

http://edamontology.org/data_1246.label: Sequence cluster (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/data_1246.description: A cluster of nucleotide sequences.|The sequences are typically related, for example a family of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1245.label: Sequence cluster (protein)
http://edamontology.org/data_1245.description: A cluster of protein sequences.|The sequences are typically related, for example a family of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1234.label: Sequence set (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/data_1234.description: Any collection of multiple nucleotide sequences and associated metadata that do not (typically) correspond to common sequence database records or database entries.

http://edamontology.org/data_1246.label: Sequence cluster (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/data_1246.description: A cluster of nucleotide sequences.|The sequences are typically related, for example a family of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1240.label: PCR primers
http://edamontology.org/data_1240.description: Oligonucleotide primer(s) for PCR and DNA amplification, for example a minimal primer set.

http://edamontology.org/data_1239.label: Restriction digest
http://edamontology.org/data_1239.description: Restriction digest fragments from digesting a nucleotide sequence with restriction sites using a restriction endonuclease.

http://edamontology.org/data_0925.label: Sequence assembly
http://edamontology.org/data_0925.description: An assembly of fragments of a (typically genomic) DNA sequence.|Typically, an assembly is a collection of contigs (for example ESTs and genomic DNA fragments) that are ordered, aligned and merged. Annotation of the assembled sequence might be included.

http://edamontology.org/data_0924.label: Sequence trace
http://edamontology.org/data_0924.description: Fluorescence trace data generated by an automated DNA sequencer, which can be interprted as a molecular sequence (reads), given associated sequencing metadata such as base-call quality scores.|This is the raw data produced by a DNA sequencing machine.

http://edamontology.org/data_1233.label: Sequence set (protein)
http://edamontology.org/data_1233.description: Any collection of multiple protein sequences and associated metadata that do not (typically) correspond to common sequence database records or database entries.

http://edamontology.org/data_1262.label: Peptide molecular weight hits
http://edamontology.org/data_1262.description: A report on peptide fragments of certain molecular weight(s) in one or more protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1245.label: Sequence cluster (protein)
http://edamontology.org/data_1245.description: A cluster of protein sequences.|The sequences are typically related, for example a family of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/data_1238.label: Proteolytic digest
http://edamontology.org/data_1238.description: A protein sequence cleaved into peptide fragments (by enzymatic or chemical cleavage) with fragment masses.

http://edamontology.org/data_0842.label: Identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_0842.description: A text token, number or something else which identifies an entity, but which may not be persistent (stable) or unique (the same identifier may identify multiple things).

http://edamontology.org/data_2109.label: Identifier (hybrid)
http://edamontology.org/data_2109.description: An identifier that is re-used for data objects of fundamentally different types (typically served from a single database).|This branch provides an alternative organisation of the concepts nested under 'Accession' and 'Name'. All concepts under here are already included under 'Accession' or 'Name'.

http://edamontology.org/data_3274.label: MGI accession
http://edamontology.org/data_3274.description: Identifier of an object from the MGI database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2917.label: ConsensusPathDB identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_2917.description: An identifier of an entity from the ConsensusPathDB database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2777.label: ConsensusPathDB entity name
http://edamontology.org/data_2777.description: Name of a physical entity from the ConsensusPathDB database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2776.label: ConsensusPathDB entity ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2776.description: Identifier of a physical entity from the ConsensusPathDB database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2345.label: Pathway ID (ConsensusPathDB)
http://edamontology.org/data_2345.description: Identifier of a pathway from the ConsensusPathDB pathway database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2649.label: PharmGKB ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2649.description: Identifier of an entry from the pharmacogenetics and pharmacogenomics knowledge base (PharmGKB).

http://edamontology.org/data_2652.label: Drug ID (PharmGKB)
http://edamontology.org/data_2652.description: Identifier of a drug from the pharmacogenetics and pharmacogenomics knowledge base (PharmGKB).

http://edamontology.org/data_2651.label: Disease ID (PharmGKB)
http://edamontology.org/data_2651.description: Identifier of a disease from the pharmacogenetics and pharmacogenomics knowledge base (PharmGKB).

http://edamontology.org/data_2650.label: Pathway ID (PharmGKB)
http://edamontology.org/data_2650.description: Identifier of a pathway from the pharmacogenetics and pharmacogenomics knowledge base (PharmGKB).

http://edamontology.org/data_2639.label: PubChem ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2639.description: Identifier of an entry from the PubChem database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2638.label: PubChem bioassay ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2638.description: Identifier of an assay from the PubChem database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1172.label: PubChem CID
http://edamontology.org/data_1172.description: Chemical structure specified in PubChem Compound Identification (CID), a non-zero integer identifier for a unique chemical structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_2637.label: cPath ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2637.description: A unique identifier for pathways, reactions, complexes and small molecules from the cPath (Pathway Commons) database.|These identifiers are unique within the cPath database, however, they are not stable between releases.

http://edamontology.org/data_2632.label: SGD ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2632.description: Identifier of an entry from the Saccharomyces genome database (SGD).

http://edamontology.org/data_1901.label: Locus ID (SGD)
http://edamontology.org/data_1901.description: Identifier for loci from SGD (Saccharomyces Genome Database).

http://edamontology.org/data_1034.label: Gene ID (SGD)
http://edamontology.org/data_1034.description: Identifier of an entry from the SGD database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2620.label: RGD ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2620.description: Identifier of an entry from the RGD database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2610.label: Ensembl ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2610.description: Identifier of an entry (exon, gene, transcript or protein) from the Ensembl database.

http://edamontology.org/data_3270.label: Ensembl gene tree ID
http://edamontology.org/data_3270.description: Unique identifier for a gene tree from the Ensembl database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2368.description: Identifier of an exon from the ASTD database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2114.description: Protein identifier used by WormBase database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1805.description: Gene identifier used by WormBase database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1092.description: Class of an object from the WormBase database.|A WormBase class describes the type of object such as 'sequence' or 'protein'.

http://edamontology.org/data_1091.description: Name of an object from the WormBase database, usually a human-readable name.

http://edamontology.org/data_2104.description: Identifier of an object from one of the BioCyc databases.

http://edamontology.org/data_2107.description: Identifier of an enzyme from the BioCyc enzymes database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2106.description: Identifier of a biological reaction from the BioCyc reactions database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2105.description: Identifier of a compound from the BioCyc chemical compounds database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1157.description: Identifier of an pathway from the BioCyc biological pathways database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1891.label: iHOP symbol
http://edamontology.org/data_1891.description: A unique identifier of a protein or gene used in the iHOP database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1154.description: Unique identifier of an object from one of the KEGG databases (excluding the GENES division).

http://edamontology.org/data_2613.description: Unique identifier of a glycan ligand from the KEGG GLYCAN database (a subset of KEGG LIGAND).

http://edamontology.org/data_2609.label: Drug ID (KEGG)
http://edamontology.org/data_2609.description: Unique identifier of a drug from the KEGG Drug database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2608.description: Identifier of a biological reaction from the KEGG reactions database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2605.description: Unique identifier of a chemical compound from the KEGG database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2343.label: Pathway ID (KEGG)
http://edamontology.org/data_2343.description: Identifier of a pathway from the KEGG pathway database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2102.label: KEGG organism code
http://edamontology.org/data_2102.description: A three-letter code used in the KEGG databases to uniquely identify organisms.

http://edamontology.org/data_1089.label: FlyBase ID
http://edamontology.org/data_1089.description: Identifier of an object from the FlyBase database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2174.label: FlyBase secondary identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_2174.description: Secondary identifier of an object from the FlyBase database.|Secondary identifier are used to handle entries that were merged with or split from other entries in the database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2112.label: FlyBase primary identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_2112.description: Primary identifier of an object from the FlyBase database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1036.label: TIGR identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_1036.description: Identifier of an entry from the TIGR database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2099.label: Name
http://edamontology.org/data_2099.description: A name of a thing, which need not necessarily uniquely identify it.

http://edamontology.org/data_3732.label: Sequencing metadata name
http://edamontology.org/data_3732.description: Data concerning a sequencing experiment, that may be specified as an input to some tool.

http://edamontology.org/data_3735.label: Run number
http://edamontology.org/data_3735.description: A number corresponding to the number of an analysis performed by a sequencing machine.  For example, if it's the 13th analysis, the run is 13.

http://edamontology.org/data_3734.label: Lane identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_3734.description: An identifier of a lane within a flow cell of a sequencing machine, within which millions of sequences are immobilised, amplified and sequenced.

http://edamontology.org/data_3733.label: Flow cell identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_3733.description: An identifier of a flow cell of a sequencing machine.|A flow cell is used to immobilise, amplify and sequence millions of molecules at once.  In Illumina machines, a flowcell is composed of  8 "lanes" which allows 8 experiments in a single analysis.

http://edamontology.org/data_2909.label: Organism name
http://edamontology.org/data_2909.description: The name of an organism (or group of organisms).

http://edamontology.org/data_2102.label: KEGG organism code
http://edamontology.org/data_2102.description: A three-letter code used in the KEGG databases to uniquely identify organisms.

http://edamontology.org/data_1874.label: Genbank common name
http://edamontology.org/data_1874.description: Common name for an organism as used in the GenBank database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1872.label: Taxonomic classification
http://edamontology.org/data_1872.description: The full name for a group of organisms, reflecting their biological classification and (usually) conforming to a standard nomenclature.|Name components correspond to levels in a taxonomic hierarchy (e.g. 'Genus', 'Species', etc.) Meta information such as a reference where the name was defined and a date might be included.

http://edamontology.org/data_1868.label: Taxon
http://edamontology.org/data_1868.description: The name of a group of organisms belonging to the same taxonomic rank.|For a complete list of taxonomic ranks see https://www.phenoscape.org/wiki/Taxonomic_Rank_Vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/data_2732.label: Family name
http://edamontology.org/data_2732.description: The name of a family of organism.

http://edamontology.org/data_2595.label: UTRdb taxon
http://edamontology.org/data_2595.description: The name of a taxon using the controlled vocabulary of the UTRdb database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2594.label: UniGene taxon
http://edamontology.org/data_2594.description: The name of a taxon using the controlled vocabulary of the UniGene database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1875.label: NCBI taxon
http://edamontology.org/data_1875.description: The name of a taxon from the NCBI taxonomy database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1870.label: Genus name
http://edamontology.org/data_1870.description: The name of a genus of organism.

http://edamontology.org/data_1045.label: Species name
http://edamontology.org/data_1045.description: The name of a species (typically a taxonomic group) of organism.

http://edamontology.org/data_1044.label: Kingdom name
http://edamontology.org/data_1044.description: The name of a biological kingdom (Bacteria, Archaea, or Eukaryotes).

http://edamontology.org/data_1046.label: Strain name
http://edamontology.org/data_1046.description: The name of a strain of an organism variant, typically a plant, virus or bacterium.

http://edamontology.org/data_2316.label: Cell line name
http://edamontology.org/data_2316.description: The name of a cell line.

http://edamontology.org/data_2320.label: Cell line name (assonant)
http://edamontology.org/data_2320.description: The name of a cell line.

http://edamontology.org/data_2319.label: Cell line name (no punctuation)
http://edamontology.org/data_2319.description: The name of a cell line.

http://edamontology.org/data_2318.label: Cell line name (truncated)
http://edamontology.org/data_2318.description: The name of a cell line.

http://edamontology.org/data_2317.label: Cell line name (exact)
http://edamontology.org/data_2317.description: The name of a cell line.

http://edamontology.org/data_2892.label: Cell type name
http://edamontology.org/data_2892.description: The name of a type or group of cells.

http://edamontology.org/data_2791.label: Reference map name (SWISS-2DPAGE)
http://edamontology.org/data_2791.description: Name of a reference map gel from the SWISS-2DPAGE database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2777.label: ConsensusPathDB entity name
http://edamontology.org/data_2777.description: Name of a physical entity from the ConsensusPathDB database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2606.label: RFAM name
http://edamontology.org/data_2606.description: Name (not necessarily stable) an entry (RNA family) from the RFAM database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2597.label: CABRI catalogue name
http://edamontology.org/data_2597.description: The name of a catalogue of biological resources from the CABRI database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2339.label: Ontology concept name
http://edamontology.org/data_2339.description: The name of a concept in an ontology.

http://edamontology.org/data_2299.label: Gene name
http://edamontology.org/data_2299.description: The name of a gene, (typically) assigned by a person and/or according to a naming scheme. It may contain white space characters and is typically more intuitive and readable than a gene symbol. It (typically) may be used to identify similar genes in different species and to derive a gene symbol.

http://edamontology.org/data_1026.label: Gene symbol
http://edamontology.org/data_1026.description: The short name of a gene; a single word that does not contain white space characters. It is typically derived from the gene name.

http://edamontology.org/data_2253.label: Data resource definition name
http://edamontology.org/data_2253.description: The name of a data type.

http://edamontology.org/data_1163.label: MIRIAM data type name
http://edamontology.org/data_1163.description: The name of a data type from the MIRIAM database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1166.label: MIRIAM data type synonymous name
http://edamontology.org/data_1166.description: A synonymous name of a data type from the MIRIAM database.|A synonymous name for a MIRIAM data type taken from a controlled vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/data_1165.label: MIRIAM data type primary name
http://edamontology.org/data_1165.description: The primary name of a data type from the MIRIAM database.|The primary name of a MIRIAM data type is taken from a controlled vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/data_2219.label: Database field name
http://edamontology.org/data_2219.description: The name of a field in a database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2154.label: Sequence name
http://edamontology.org/data_2154.description: Any arbitrary name of a molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/data_2291.label: UniProt ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2291.description: An identifier of a polypeptide in the UniProt database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2133.label: Logical operator
http://edamontology.org/data_2133.description: A logical operator such as OR, AND, XOR, and NOT.

http://edamontology.org/data_2131.label: Operating system name
http://edamontology.org/data_2131.description: Name of a computer operating system such as Linux, PC or Mac.

http://edamontology.org/data_2129.label: File format name
http://edamontology.org/data_2129.description: Name of a file format such as HTML, PNG, PDF, EMBL, GenBank and so on.

http://edamontology.org/data_2254.label: OBO file format name
http://edamontology.org/data_2254.description: Name of an OBO file format such as OBO-XML, plain and so on.

http://edamontology.org/data_2128.label: Genetic code name
http://edamontology.org/data_2128.description: Informal name for a genetic code, typically an organism name.

http://edamontology.org/data_1867.description: The name of a protein fold.

http://edamontology.org/data_1807.label: ORF name
http://edamontology.org/data_1807.description: The name of an open reading frame attributed by a sequencing project.

http://edamontology.org/data_1748.description: Identifier (a string) of a specific atom from a PDB file for a molecular structure.

http://edamontology.org/data_2782.label: SMART domain name
http://edamontology.org/data_2782.description: Name of a domain from the SMART database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2757.label: Pfam domain name
http://edamontology.org/data_2757.description: Name of a domain from the Pfam database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1132.label: InterPro entry name
http://edamontology.org/data_1132.description: Name of an InterPro entry, usually indicating the type of protein matches for that entry.

http://edamontology.org/data_1126.label: Comparison matrix name
http://edamontology.org/data_1126.description: Unique name or identifier of a comparison matrix.|See for example http://www.ebi.ac.uk/Tools/webservices/help/matrix.

http://edamontology.org/data_1095.label: EMBOSS Uniform Sequence Address
http://edamontology.org/data_1095.description: The name of a sequence-based entity adhering to the standard sequence naming scheme used by all EMBOSS applications.

http://edamontology.org/data_1091.label: WormBase name
http://edamontology.org/data_1091.description: Name of an object from the WormBase database, usually a human-readable name.

http://edamontology.org/data_1076.label: Codon usage table name
http://edamontology.org/data_1076.description: Unique name of a codon usage table.

http://edamontology.org/data_1056.label: Database name
http://edamontology.org/data_1056.description: The name of a biological or bioinformatics database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1051.label: Ontology name
http://edamontology.org/data_1051.description: Name of an ontology of biological or bioinformatics concepts and relations.

http://edamontology.org/data_1050.label: File name
http://edamontology.org/data_1050.description: The name (or part of a name) of a file (of any type).

http://edamontology.org/data_1060.label: File base name
http://edamontology.org/data_1060.description: The base name of a file.|A file base name is the file name stripped of its directory specification and extension.

http://edamontology.org/data_1059.label: File name extension
http://edamontology.org/data_1059.description: The extension of a file name.|A file extension is the characters appearing after the final '.' in the file name.

http://edamontology.org/data_1058.label: Enumerated file name
http://edamontology.org/data_1058.description: The name of a file (of any type) with restricted possible values.

http://edamontology.org/data_1023.label: EMBOSS Uniform Feature Object
http://edamontology.org/data_1023.description: The name of a sequence feature-containing entity adhering to the standard feature naming scheme used by all EMBOSS applications.

http://edamontology.org/data_1022.label: Sequence feature label
http://edamontology.org/data_1022.description: A name of a sequence feature, e.g. the name of a feature to be displayed to an end-user. Typically an EMBL or Swiss-Prot feature label.|A feature label identifies a feature of a sequence database entry. When used with the database name and the entry's primary accession number, it is a unique identifier of that feature.

http://edamontology.org/data_2775.label: Kinase name
http://edamontology.org/data_2775.description: The name of a kinase protein.

http://edamontology.org/data_2764.label: Protein name (UniProt)
http://edamontology.org/data_2764.description: Official name of a protein as used in the UniProt database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2755.label: Transcription factor name
http://edamontology.org/data_2755.description: The name of a transcription factor.

http://edamontology.org/data_0990.label: Compound name
http://edamontology.org/data_0990.description: Unique name of a chemical compound.

http://edamontology.org/data_1007.label: Nucleotide code
http://edamontology.org/data_1007.description: String of one or more ASCII characters representing a nucleotide.

http://edamontology.org/data_1005.label: HET group name
http://edamontology.org/data_1005.description: 3-letter code word for a ligand (HET group) from a PDB file, for example ATP.

http://edamontology.org/data_1001.label: Chemical name (synonymous)
http://edamontology.org/data_1001.description: Synonymous name of a chemical compound.

http://edamontology.org/data_1000.label: Chemical name (brand)
http://edamontology.org/data_1000.description: Brand name of a chemical compound.

http://edamontology.org/data_0999.label: Chemical name (INN)
http://edamontology.org/data_0999.description: International Non-proprietary Name (INN or 'generic name') of a chemical compound, assigned by the World Health Organisation (WHO).

http://edamontology.org/data_0998.label: Chemical name (IUPAC)
http://edamontology.org/data_0998.description: IUPAC recommended name of a chemical compound.

http://edamontology.org/data_0997.label: Chemical name (ChEBI)
http://edamontology.org/data_0997.description: Unique name from Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI) of a chemical compound.|This is the recommended chemical name for use for example in database annotation.

http://edamontology.org/data_2706.label: Chromosome name (BioCyc)
http://edamontology.org/data_2706.description: Name of a chromosome as used in the BioCyc database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2091.label: Accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2091.description: A persistent (stable) and unique identifier, typically identifying an object (entry) from a database.

http://edamontology.org/data_3667.label: Disease identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_3667.description: Identifier of an entry from a database of disease.

http://edamontology.org/data_1150.label: Disease ID
http://edamontology.org/data_1150.description: Accession number of an entry from a database of disease.

http://edamontology.org/data_2800.label: Orpha number
http://edamontology.org/data_2800.description: An identifier of a disease from the Orpha database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2651.label: Disease ID (PharmGKB)
http://edamontology.org/data_2651.description: Identifier of a disease from the pharmacogenetics and pharmacogenomics knowledge base (PharmGKB).

http://edamontology.org/data_2611.label: ICD identifier
http://edamontology.org/data_2611.description: An identifier of a disease from the International Classification of Diseases (ICD) database.

http://edamontology.org/data_3274.label: MGI accession
http://edamontology.org/data_3274.description: Identifier of an object from the MGI database.

http://edamontology.org/data_3273.label: Sample ID
http://edamontology.org/data_3273.description: Name or other identifier of an entry from a biosample database.

http://edamontology.org/data_3022.label: NCBI genetic code ID
http://edamontology.org/data_3022.description: Identifier of a genetic code in the NCBI list of genetic codes.

http://edamontology.org/data_2911.label: Transcription factor accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2911.description: Accession of an entry from a database of transcription factors or binding sites.

http://edamontology.org/data_2742.label: AraC-XylS ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2742.description: Identifier of a transcription factor from the AraC-XylS database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2716.label: DBD ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2716.description: Identifier of a predicted transcription factor from the DBD database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1143.label: TRANSFAC accession number
http://edamontology.org/data_1143.description: Identifier of an entry from the TRANSFAC database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2910.label: Protein family accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2910.description: Accession of a protein family (that is deposited in a database).

http://edamontology.org/data_2783.label: Protein family ID (PANTHER)
http://edamontology.org/data_2783.description: Accession number of an entry (family) from the PANTHER database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2766.label: HAMAP ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2766.description: Name of a protein family from the HAMAP database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2758.label: Pfam clan ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2758.description: Accession number of a Pfam clan.

http://edamontology.org/data_2731.label: Protein family ID (GeneFarm)
http://edamontology.org/data_2731.description: Accession number of an entry (family) from the TIGRFam database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2614.label: TCDB ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2614.description: A unique identifier of a family from the transport classification database (TCDB) of membrane transport proteins.|OBO file for regular expression.

http://edamontology.org/data_1142.label: ProDom accession number
http://edamontology.org/data_1142.description: A ProDom domain family accession number.|ProDom is a protein domain family database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1141.label: TIGRFam ID
http://edamontology.org/data_1141.description: Accession number of an entry (family) from the TIGRFam database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1140.label: Superfamily hidden Markov model number
http://edamontology.org/data_1140.description: Unique identifier (number) of a hidden Markov model from the Superfamily database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1139.label: SMART accession number
http://edamontology.org/data_1139.description: Accession number of an entry from the SMART database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1138.label: Pfam accession number
http://edamontology.org/data_1138.description: Accession number of a Pfam entry.

http://edamontology.org/data_1137.label: PRINTS code
http://edamontology.org/data_1137.description: The unique identifier of an entry in the PRINTS database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1136.label: PIRSF ID
http://edamontology.org/data_1136.description: Unique identifier of an entry from the PIRSF database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1135.label: Gene3D ID
http://edamontology.org/data_1135.description: Unique identifier of an entry from the Gene3D database.

http://edamontology.org/data_1133.label: InterPro accession
http://edamontology.org/data_1133.description: Primary accession number of an InterPro entry.|Every InterPro entry has a unique accession number to provide a persistent citation of database records.

http://edamontology.org/data_1134.label: InterPro secondary accession
http://edamontology.org/data_1134.description: Secondary accession number of an InterPro entry.

http://edamontology.org/data_2908.label: Organism accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2908.description: An accession of annotation on a (group of) organisms (catalogued in a database).

http://edamontology.org/data_2912.label: Strain accession
http://edamontology.org/data_2912.description: Identifier of a strain of an organism variant, typically a plant, virus or bacterium.

http://edamontology.org/data_2778.label: CCAP strain number
http://edamontology.org/data_2778.description: The number of a strain of algae and protozoa from the CCAP database.

http://edamontology.org/data_2785.label: Virus ID
http://edamontology.org/data_2785.description: An accession of annotation on a (group of) viruses (catalogued in a database).

http://edamontology.org/data_2836.label: DPVweb ID

http://edamontology.org/data_2315.description: An identifier assigned to sequence records processed by NCBI, made of the accession number of the database record followed by a dot and a version number.|Nucleotide sequence version contains two letters followed by six digits, a dot, and a version number (or for older nucleotide sequence records, the format is one letter followed by five digits, a dot, and a version number). http://edamontology.org/data_2314.description: A series of digits that are assigned consecutively to each sequence record processed by NCBI. Protein sequence GI number is shown in the CDS/db_xref field of a nucleotide database record, and the VERSION field of a protein database record.

http://edamontology.org/data_3029.label: Protein ID (EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ)
http://edamontology.org/data_3029.description: EMBL/GENBANK/DDBJ coding feature protein identifier, issued by International collaborators.|This qualifier consists of a stable ID portion (3+5 format with 3 position letters and 5 numbers) plus a version number after the decimal point. When the protein sequence encoded by the CDS changes, only the version number of the /protein_id value is incremented; the stable part of the /protein_id remains unchanged and as a result will permanently be associated with a given protein; this qualifier is valid only on CDS features which translate into a valid protein.
